Cities: Skylines Review:  I wrote down what my reaction was to each day I had the game up until the release date (March 10).  Day 1(March 4th)(I received the game at about 9:00 PM EST, but failed to check my email, I checked my email at about 11:00 PM EST and immediately downloaded the game)  As I opened the game it completely lost me in its blue color. I immediately started playing, I couldn't wait another second. I started my first city. As I look at the roads I notice that the only road I have unlocked is a 2way road. That made me confused. Why would I place a road just to delete it? What I mean is that I placed it on the highway ramps to come into/leave the city. As I place the 1 way 2 lane roads I think, 'Where do I start'? As I start to plan my city, my friend home rings, it is right next to me, completely ignore it. I could not move away. I played for about an hour before realizing I need to go to bed.  Day 2(March 5th) I wake up at about 5:30 to 6:00 AM EST. I hurry to get myself ready, I'm about 25 minutes early than I usually am. What did I do? What do you think I did? I hopped back on Cities: Skylines. I played for about 20 minutes only to realize that I had to part from my computer. Once I came home I played for about 3:00 PM EST to 1:00 AM EST(10 hours) before going to bed.  Day 3(March 6th) Played from about 7:00 AM EST to 1:00 AM EST. I could not stop playing! Built my city up and thought that I should start a new one. Started 'Stockholm'.   Day 4(March 7th) I didn't get much playing time in, only about an hour total.   Day 5(March 8th) Played about 10:00 AM EST to 11:00 AM EST and about 5:30 PM EST to 1:00 AM EST  Day 6(March 9th) Played a little. Maybe about 2 hours.   As of this writing, I have played this game for 35.1 hours. So almost 1.5 days in 6 days. Wow. This game is great.  Pros: The detail. The fact you can see 'poop water' floating away is great. The water dynamics are really really good. The fact that you can run a small farm town instead of building up to a huge city is really really cool. Running a small farm town is great.  Cons: Game doesn't run great on laptops, especially huge cities. Traffic is a little too congested on the graphs. What I mean is if you use the traffic info view traffic on a road/intersection is weighed to heavily towards the red. Traffic is a huge issue.  Rank: 8/10  Side effects of playing: Addiction Have an extremely fun time creating the city of your dreams

I want to start off by firstly saying if you are expecting a 'OMFG BEST CITY BUILDA GAME EVA!!!!!!!' post, then you'll be disappointed. Don't get me wrong, Skylines is a great game, but I would not call it the best city builder ever.  To be able to do that, we would have to compare how Skylines is against its two main rivals, SimCity 2013 (EA) and Cities XXL (FHI). It is my opinion that all three games are good games that stand on their own feet. Okay, SimCity 2013 only has one foot, and a severely disabled one at that, but it does bring some good to the genre.  Take for instance, modular service buildings in SC2013. These were pretty ace! Expand a service building over time as the neighborhood grew and required more/additional services. SC2013 also carried over the fantastic Rush Hour concept from SC4. This allowed the game to really stretch your transport networks to the limits during a simulated city rush hour.  In another corner, Cities XXL brought huge lifelike maps to the genre, the ability to not just create a single city but an entire region in one encompassing map. This took SimCity 4's region view to the next level. And probably because of the regional map, XXL's rural possibilities, including rural towns and farming, are far and away the highlight of a game beset with numerous issues.  Skylines on the other hand doesn't appear to include these 3 game concepts (yet, maybe future dlc?). But Skylines brings other concepts to the genre. Districts is nothing short of a brilliant addition to the genre. Now you can specify separate districts (call them suburbs if you want) and specify city policies to specialise each district. Now you can have a timber district, oil district, heavy industry district, upper class residential district all with their own city and transport policies. The use of the Unity engine for Skylines opens up an entire plethora of modding potential in the game. Already on day 1 we can see full map unlock mods, Chirpy killer mods and many others. The potential of what modders can add to the game is nearly limitless.  But like SC2013's severely handicapped map sizes, and XXL's defunct game engine, Skylines has it's own share of issues. Chirpy has become the most hated item of the game. There is no way to turn it off without the use of a mod (which stops achievements being gained). The 9 map tile limit (out of 25) is a purely insane decision by the developers. People have already proven that due to the map not impacting CPU usage (CPU usage is impacted by population) that the story of 'oh we limited map tiles due to hardware limits' is total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. It's this person's opinion that a 25 tile unlock dlc was in the pipeline to be fed to us all for $5. But now we'll never know. That of course brings me to my next point. Paradox is famous for dlc's. Now whether you agree with the way PDX does dlc or not is irrelevant to me. Just know that Crusader Kings 2 (PDX has already openly stated that the dlc model for Skylines is the same as CK2) has 53 dlc for a cost of $185 USD. With the base game costing $40 USD still it means to get a complete CK2 you're up for $225 USD. Don't argue with me on the point, but try to justify how the 53 dlc for CK2 is the equivalent of 9 old-style $20 expansion packs.  So I suppose the bottom line is this. Cities Skylines is a good game. But I would not call it the best city builder ever. Understand that SimCity 2013, Cities XXL and Cities Skylines all have their own positives and negatives. Where one lacks, another picks up. Do I recommend you pick up Cities Skylines? Sure, but don't expect it to be the perfect game. I don't see that happening until 3 years and 50 dlc down the track.

This is a relaxing game with decent graphics and sound. It's mostly focused on traffic management, and though that may sound boring, it's not. It's alot less complex than simcity games, and as far as traffic is concerned, much more detailed. It's the only city builder I've played where there is very little consequence for destroying huge areas of businesses or houses so you can make room for a new highway and a few dozen ramps, or whipe out half your business district so you can put in a nice train depot. It seems like new businesses will just pop right up and it doesn't cost a penalty. The biggest expense would be the roads in the above case. Want to move a $20k firehouse? There's move buttons for almost all special buildings so it only costs about 10% to scoot it over a block, or out of the way of an elevator walk-path. The day/night cycle, and now rain, gives it some nice ambience.  There are several good mods out there and tons of assets that you can subscribe to on the workshop. And though it's encouraged to do this, it will slow your computer with tons of assets, and the mods will prevent achievements from being earned, which is very annoying.  And though it feels complete, it also feels like it falls short for some reason. I think it's from a lack of real challenges. The hard mode simply raises prices 10%, but after playing a while you basically have unlimited money. And aside from population, there's no real goals in this game. There is no reason to have a huge manufacturing town or farming community. There's no tornados, riots, or even upset people for that matter. Happiness is almost always high unless you forget to give them water, or electricity. Overall I would rate this in between a thumbs up and down, but leaning towards up. 3 out of 5 star.

This game almost got it all. Roundabouts, highways above and under the ground, expandable cities, moddable, etc.  No crappy micro transactions like Tropico, no 250+ massive bugs like Sim City 2014. no lies, no EA. Just a good game.  It feels a bit like a care-bear city where nothing happens. I miss driving through town, doing simple silly missions like in Sim City 4, taking control of cars or just something... Also a very few minor balance issues. But aside from that it is the first city simulator that I enjoyed since a very very long time.

While this game is fun it has more of a traffic management angle. It's very easy to get the buildings to top level (only 5 levels) and to come out on top financially. You will spend most of your time trying to figure out how to better manage the 9+ types of roads the game has and planning bus stops and sub ways. I am use to playing Pharoah (each building has 25 levels and depends on many types of goods and services and no traffic) so that's where I am coming from.

Definitely the best City-Building game available, they've really thought everything through and added all the little things that make this a fun, realistic and engaging game. You get to plan everything from zoning, traffic, public transport lines, types of industry and even socio-economic policies.   If that wasn't enough, the Workshop abounds with amazing work from the community that meshes well with the game. Want a more efficient trash collection system? Done. More unique buildings to better your skyline? Done. Want an in-depth mod that regulates all traffic, public transport and pedestrian access whilt simultaneously creating additional roads/lanes/passageways for buses and emergency vehicles? Done!  Amazing game, great community. Do yourself a favor and buy this gem.

Cities: Skylines is one of my all-time favourite games. Ever.  Cities' is the perfect city building simulation game on the market right now and is going to lead the way for future city simulation games. The modding API and EASE of modding makes this game even better than it already is. The vanilla game is expansive with multiple public transport options, many different building styles, themes, cars and people. THE PEOPLE. Everyone and i mean EVERYONE has a random name, random job and random place they live in. You can follow one person to wherever they go. It makes it feel like a real city. Everyone has their own objective and place to be. Every car and pedestrian has a story.  There is so much replayablity due to the fact of ENDLESS maps on the Steam Workshop that make every city look completely different from your last. The sheer scale of everything from highways and skyscrapers makes this such an immersive experience. The only problem i have with the game is the traffic. Constant line ups of cars who REFUSE to go into multiple lanes on a highway or road gets really annoying. I am yet to find a proper solution.  In conclusion; Everyone who is interested in simulation and city building, this is a must have for them. The game is so replayable and will give you hours of entertainment. Can't wait for futher additions

Advanced traffic management techniques are usually required especially in the late game if you don't want dead people piling up in one part of the city amongst other problems. My only real gripe is the limits with the Unity engine (From what I've read) in that my city has grown enough such that I get the 'Cannot create anymore objects of this type' so it's not possible to expand my city beyond a certain limit. I watched all the videos, I watched all the streams, I floowed the hype for this game rather intently for about a month leading up to its release. This game meets or excedes the amount of hype that was built up about it. One might even argue that due to it being exactly what it was advertised to be that it was not hype at all, but them just advertising their product honestly and plainly.   This game is a rare example of what be achieved with a bit of love for what you are doing.  Cities: Skylines is definitely not without its flaws though. In most cases those flaws could be modded out of the game and the remainder of the problems could potentially be overlooked. The game is good enough that the flaws it does have just don't really seem to be too much of a problem. That is a lot coming from someone who happens to be very critical and I am very critical of products that are up for purchase consideration.  The price is excelent for this game too. I am not one to shy away from pirating software but this game, due to its price and the amount of satisfaction I get while playing it, it is worth every penny, no doubt. No buyers remorse nor guilt. Just a good product for a good price.  Thanks to Colossal Order, today is a very good day to be a fan of the city simulation genre.  This game is truly amazing.

Cities: Skylines is a very good city builder game for anyone that doesn't want to buy DRM-city (Simcity)  Cities: Skylines is one of the best city builders I've played in a long time. To be fair, most of them were free to play and relied heavily on microtransations and timers. Recently, I've purchased this game and also the lastest Simcity game (2013). I purchased Simcity on origin and regret it to this day.  This particular game gives you alot of freedom when you compare to the disaster that was Simcity (2013). One of the main things is that you don't have to play exclusivly online which makes sense since City-Builders are singleplayer games and the multiplayer elements in Simcity weren't even that useful.  The main market for Cities:Skylines seems to be the ability to mod as you are able to create your city exactly how you want, you are able to get different design schemes for buildings or entirely new building adding new mechanics to the game.  Cities is able to run decently on most computers however, older computers will struggle when numerous entities are on the screen such as car, people, trains, etc. This is something to consider when picking up this game.  A bad thing about game is how overpriced the DLC is for the little amount of content in it. Another thing I find a bit stupid in this game is the mechanics for waterpipes and powerlines, in this right, I would say Simcity was better at this than Cities is. In simcity, the pipes are built into the road and power travels through the road. The only time you would need power lines or piping is if you have an area of town that was not connected to the main roads for some reason. This is just nitpicking though.  However in cities, you have endless possiblities and customization options with mods and level editors that should be able to fix some of these problem for you.  Overall, I would recommend this game to any who whats to build a city.  10/10

This game is fantastic and is better then Simcity 2013, you start off with a plot of land, you lay the roads down and you zone the residental, commercial and industrial and you plop down a power plant and a water pump, as well as a sewage pump, as your town grows the town levels up and you get new things like fire stations, clinics and other things, and once you level up some more you get to buy a plot of land so your city can grow bigger, which Simcity did not have, and you continue to grow the city, as you build your city you can run into some big problems, like traffic and you having no money, and when those problems start to happen things get worse, for example a house can be burning down but the fire trucks can get there becuase of traffic, and the building will become abandoned and then criminals will start to move in becuase of the low land value and then they start crimes and the cops wont be able to get them because of traffic and the fire trucks, and then people die and herses or whatever their called need to get the dead people but the traffic is causing the herses to not get the dead people on time and then the building that they died in becomes abandoned and it goes on and on, and in Simcity if that problem happend your city was in big trouble, but you can fix the problems with a bit of hard work, and even a city thats is dead can rise back up again.       When you get bored of the land your building you city on you can always pick a new one since there is 9 maps or you can make your own map using the map editor thingy, you can make a map where its all flat or you can make a map where there is moutains all around the map, and you can go onto the steam workshop and subscribe maps that other people made and use them, and also there is the asset editor which is a tool where you can customize buildings and more, and you can use 3D modling tools or whatever their called to make your own buildings, people have made little restruants like McDonalds and made landmarks, and you can subscribe to mods and use them to flood your city or to customize the game.       This game is a really fun game and its even more fun with steam workshop, but there is a few bugs. If you love city builder games then buy this. 9.5/10

This isn't a bad game. But it isn't worth it's full price.  When you launch it, you will like it. It is fun, and it has many options that SimCity didn't have.  However, the fun burns down VERY quickly. There is no challenge (sure, you can increase the difficulty, but it feels artificial). When you have a big city, all you can do is speed up the game so you have enough money to buy monuments. And that's it.  The lack of secretaries (like SimCity 4) also makes the game a bit too artificial.  But, it is still very fun, and i don't think my money was wasted because it was on sale. And, if it is on sale, and you want a new experience with a city simulator, Cities Skylines is not a bad option. But don't get fooled: It isn't the game everyone says it is. It is a fun simulator that gets boring too quickly, and that's it.  I wasn't sure if i would upvote the game or not, but, for the sake of honesty, i recommend it, if you buy it on sale. I will probably play it every now and then, but, after the initial hype, i doubt i will spend hours and hours building another city.

Roads are so unrealistic that is ridiculous. IE can't split six-lane highway to 2 three-lane. I mean, I can but not the way it is sensible for a road to be split - three lanes are pushed towards each other and three lanes deviate - in real life the leftmost three lanes just continue straight ahead and the 3 lanes to the right deviate - unfortunately not in Cities Skylines. Ramps off highway are at ridiculous high angle and even if you use the sharp angle mod it is still too much. Now, that might not be a problem for a lot of players but it is just disastrous to me as the same company made CIM2 where roads are built in a lot more realistic manner. Why?! Why did you change that? :( Game for me is ruined because of this. Everything else is top 10 out of 10, really. But this nonsense, given the fact CIM2 has the perfect road system a game can have... I know, it is probably not as annoying to other players as it is to me so that is why I still recommend the game.

This game stil has a lot of potential. While it's already a great game there are a few things that may anoy you or are just bad design choices. Basically SimCity 2.0 but a little less 'polished', and a lot of features that you wished were in it in the first place. I've only played it at the time of this reveiw for a couple of hours and can say that I do really enjoy this game.    Pros  - Runs silky smooth. Even if I unlock all 25 build squares I'm at a constant 60+FPS, will need to update this in future when I make some large cities. - Steam workshop support - 9, 2x2km^2 tiles, moddable up to 25 or 100km^2!!! - Import your own heightmaps and create your own worlds - Pretty to look at. - Takes ideas from SimCity and makes them better!   Cons  Longer list but don't worry, they're only minor issues that are easily work-roundable - User Interface Needs some serious work. Chirpy is the most anoyying AF thing by far. But it could be less anoyying and more useful if they moved it to one of the two big empty spaces in the bottom UI bar. Icons need updating. Some are slightly bland, and some are just too random to understand what they are. In-game icons or warnings above houses are very very difficult to understand or make out at times unless you click the building to find out what the problem is. A simple mouse over display would be nicer. Tutorial dialog is awful, it places dialogs infront of buttons that you need to click to access certain things. I hate having to close every single one each time. - Traffic Who knows how traffic works? Road placement is nice, but It only shows you a help grid once you start placing a road down. - Sounds In-game sounds are not the greatest. I turned my music off and set the SFX to low. Personal preference - Tutorial Not much of a tutorial, you're left to figure out a lot of stuff on your own.  There should be a tutorial world. Every time you start a new city you have to complete the set tutorial and unlock everything the same way each time. After I've done it once or twice I know what I have to do. - Limited video options Would like some better AA options.

This game was clearly designed to be the better Sim City 2013 as it has been pointed out many times before. Suffice to say that Colossal Order have succeeded in doing so. But they have gone one step beyond that and put some thought and possibly years of experience as city building gamers themselves into their product. The ability to name city districts and issue separate policies being just my favorite little thing they added.  Cities: Skylines comes with in-house mod support and integrated Steam Workshop. Only a few days after the release Steam Workshop was filling and my guess is, that this game will spawn a thriving mod scene. Publisher Paradox Interactive has shown in the past that they are quite able in maintaining their titles. Not only their (now former) flagship Europa Universalis IV receives regular updates and the occasional free DLC. My hope is that Colossal Order will follow their lead in that.  There are a few negative points though: The game suffers a bit of a lack of variation. In the early game you have very little variety in leisure building. I would like to see a bit more than parks, plazas and playgrounds. At least a early game sports park or swimming pool would have been nice. Also there is not really much of an alternative to building forestry or farming industry if you decide to go clean. While you can build offices which count as industry it would have been nice to have something like a High Tech Industry which needs highly educated workers, still produces goods and is cleaner than generic industry. Now I know that these things can – and will be, I can assure you that! – easily be fixed by a mod or two but it would have been nice to see them in the vanilla game nonetheless.  To summarize: The overwhelming amount of positive reviews here on steam alone should tell you that this games resonates with a lot of players. If you are a fan of the Sim City franchise this game is a must have.  tl;dr: Go buy this game. You will receive good value for your money.

Oh my god... I cannot believe how much fun I am having with this game. I haven't really played city building sim that I've enjoyed in a long time. I avoided the new SimCity like the plague for the DRM stance and I have a really bad internet connection. Then I tried Cities in Motion and Cities XL and subsequently XXL (Big mistake) and they just didn't really feel very good to play and more to the point they weren't fun. I felt no sense of achievement as I progressed. They were overloaded with issues which I won't go into, but most importantly to me they were NOT fun. So I always had to go back to SimCity 4+Rush Hour.  Now this game I have to say is extremely easy and simple to pick up. It is extremely easy to learn and it is extremely easy to play. That does not mean though that it isn't a fully fledged meat filled City Simulator with much depth. It is all that and more. I bought it last night, downloaded it which took a good amount of time and fired it up tonight. I fully expected it to have issues and not be particularly fun as that is the experience I've come to expect from games. Boy was I wrong. It's not buggy, I haven't really encountered any issues and it is amazingly fun. It isn't even filled with the annoying SimCity issue where pretty much right off the bat once you start building your city you have to start fiddling with the budget just to get a positive cashflow. The game play is solid, extremely solid. The fact that you go through it and you actually feel a sense of progression and it isn't really that hard while still providing you with the depth and fun that I find rare in these genre's is refreshing. Ironically the only issues I've had with this game are that it crashes when I close the game, which isn't really an issue because it doesn't matter if it crashes when I've exited. Second that there isn't a proper DRM-free version of the game. I would buy this game 5 times over for a proper DRM-free (non-steam) version of this game.  If you like any sort of Simulation, (City/Economic/Sandbox/etc) then definitely pick this one up. While I haven't played the new SimCity, everything I've read and watched about it tells me that this title... is what SimCity should have been. This is SimCity done right. Minus the brand, but imo this brand should overtake Maxis/SimCity in the city building department. It is THAT good.

I've been playing Cities: Skylines for a couple of hours now, and I feel like I have been getting the hang of the game.  The game is playable on launch day. It's an unfortunate truth of games today that many times, you can not launch a game for several hours due to server DRM measures. With this game, you just download it, and launch it, and maybe add a few mods. This me without a negative impression of the game right off the bat, and allowed me to get straight into the meat of this game.  The game graphically is good, but not impressive. From zoomed out, the cities seem fine, but as you zoom in, textures become less impressive. This is one of the only bad things I have to say, and considering that this game was created by a small development team, its more of a minor annoyance. Hopefully the developers or the modding community comes up with a high resolution texture pack in the next few months.  The music of the game is okay. It's not memorable, but it isn't blaring in your ears for hours to the point of annoyance. It's really just there to add some minor ambiance.  Gameplay is fun. I feel like I'm managing a city, and I have to micromanage every intersection in order to avoid crippling traffic jams. I can build my city the way I want to and not be too constrained by a small box for my city. I am a little perturbed by the way roads work when snapping together, and will often spend a lot of time working on a highway exit.  Overall, the experience has been enjoyable so far, and I look forward to many more hours of playing this game (which there will be plenty of, unlike a certain competitor that came out 2 years ago).   Happy gaming - Droen

Maxis is dead. Long live Maxis.  The city simulator genre is back, and not from who you'd expect. This is a classic take on the genre, with more modern graphics. Basically, SimCity 4 but prettier. That's a good thing.  There are some annoyances - the Chirper won't shut up, and people can never get enough hospitals (there's some serious hypochrondia going on when you need an ambulance per house). I hope they'll iterate on this over time. They seem to have humor and attention to detail - and most importantly, they're not Maxis - so I have reason to be hopeful.  I'm so glad this has come along. I've been waiting longingly for a serious city sim for so long. SimCity (the reboot) got my hopes up and then they were largely shattered. I had basically given up hope. Now Cities: Skylines shows me there's still the possibility for this genre to thrive.  It's funny how much has changed since the last good city came out. Smartphone, HDTVs, quad-core processors, Obama... and yet the city sim formula is still appealing. No, city sims are not dead. Long live city sims.
Pretty much everything SC 2013 should have been.

--Initial review at 19.1 hours--  Cities: Skylines has given me a great experience so far. Simply put, it's like Sim City if a bunch of corporate wigs didn't tell the developers 'This is what people want in a city sim, and this is how we're telling you to make it'  It's well thought out, there is attention to detail, and is a welcome new addition to the city sim genre.  That being said, it isn't perfect.  Pros:  -Well thought out game mechanics -The ability to draw out districts and enact policies in both specific districts and overall city policy. -Nice attention to detail with emergency services. As a person involved in the fire service, it's nice seeing that a firetruck in game doesn't just pull up and start shooting water at the building. One or two will show up, a few firemen get out of each and either run into the building or stand near the trucks and get hoses set up, and then the water will start flowing. It's not really important overall, but it's an appreciated detail. -Diverse power grid options ranging from coal and oil to solar, two kinds of wind, and hydroelectric. The only addition to that list that I'd like to see is some form of hydrogen power source. -Makes fun of Sim City in many ways, including achievement names, base city size, and other things. -Zoning is easy and has a layer of customization to it.  Cons: -There appears to be a self-zoning bug of some sort. I have tried to dezone an area between two roads but it keeps rezoning itself to low-density commercial. -The game doesn't always provide clear feedback to what an issue is and how to resolve it. Some issues are fairly simple to trouble shoot, but currently my city is having an issue with a lack of buyers of products from my industrial buildings, but there is no industrial, commercial, or residential demand. -The game takes a bit of patience to learn. It took me five or six tries before I created a successful city. -Some of the requirements for the unique buildings are counter-productive. Some ask you to have an obsurd number of abandoned buildings present in your city or to have a certain number of sick citizens. Compared to the other requirements like having three filled cemetaries, doing well in this sector, that sector, et cetera, those requirements are backwards and the negative concequences outway the good of unlocking the unique building. It's counter intuitive. -No day-night cycle.  Suggestions: -It would be nice to see a few more types of unique buildings or a rework of the requirements to unlocking the existing ones. -After a certain amount of time has passed for you to get your city up and running, it would be nice to see the introduction of emergencies, disasters, and other events occur that you must deal with. Perhaps things from hurricanes, snowstorms, riots, to water pipes bursting and such, et cetera. It would also allow for new polcies to be added such as putting your city into a state of emergency, curfews, gun control, citizens must shovel their portion of sidewalk during snow storms (Save money, decrease happiness), and more. -Perhaps a new utility being created for the road department. Street sweepers can help reduce ground polution, roads can degrade and you'll have to spend money to keep them maintained from pot holes and such, if snowstorms are added then snowplows would be important. -Adding the homeless could be interesting. Increased crime rates in areas they squat. You could combat that by building shelters, soup kitchens, or outlawing homelessness if you're feeling particularly evil. -It would be nice if parks didn't have to be placed right along a road, so you could put a playground in the middle of a bunch of high rises and have walking paths leading to them. -Perhaps adding a mayor's office that could be upgraded to allow for certain buffs or allow citizens to come to you with city propositions, requests, and complaints.  At this point in time, I'd give this game an 8/10. It's very well made, but there's a lot of room for improvement. After a decent amount of time, there's not much residential, industrial, or commercial demand and the challenge wears off.  If you have the money to spare, I'd say that you should buy this game at it's full price or wait for a sale.

Wow. Just wow. As a veteran Simcity 4 player, I never thought I'd jump the Maxis ship. I saw the hype online, the 30 dollar price tag, the day one modding support, and the way the dev and publisher conducted themselves online, and it convinced me to take the plunge. I'm glad I did. The hours have melted by this sunday, and I hardly believe I just sank 8 hours in one sitting with ease. This is like discovering Simcity all over again. Its full of color, micro management, and zoning. Its all so simple, yet very complex under the surface, giving you plenty to work towards.   This is a game with difficulty as well, which I'm very happy about. I managed to kill off two cities before getting the swing of things. There are a few things I have issues with though: I'd like to see a route checking tool similar to Simcity 4's. It allowed you to see what routes your sims took to work, or shopping or what ever. It gave information on what mode of transport they took, and congestion and volume data. Cities has congestion data, but you don't get as much information as I'm used too. I guess that's my major issue, not enough data. I have no doubt that the devs will include plenty of updates and expansions in the future, many of which they have said will be free. Now that's value. I whole heartly recommend this game.

A state of the art City Simulation game.   With Cities Skylines, you are put into the role of a Mayor.  You start out with 1 Tile of land, you must then populate that tile and once you reach certain milestones you will be able to expand to other tiles.  Each tile is unique, each tile has its own resources such as forests, agricultural land, ore, oil, water its then up to you to take use of these resources and 'specialize' the industry.   You will also have to maintain a network of water pipes, and make sure they function properly. There's also a interesting power grid that you will have to make sure is functioning properly. Next to that, you will have to maintain the infrastructure of your city which plays an enourmous role later in the game. So think twice before placing that one way road!   The graphics are extremely well for the game aswell, when you zoom in you can see a lot of the detail. There's even a first person mod, where you can walk amongst your citizens in eye-height.   All in all i give this game 9.50/10  It is by far the greatest city simulation i have ever seen and played.

As a sim builder since 1988 it takes a lot to impress me, after being let down by the massive potential SimCity showed, a replacement was long overdue and much needed.  This game has ticked all the boxes for a 2015 Sim game, considering all the comparisons of the former rival it stands up extremely well.  Sure there are a few features missing (tunnels), 2 lane 1-way streets, odd bugs / AI behaviour (traffic) to tweak, but there are great new features, public transport routing, regional polices, dynamic electric dams… plus I could play it on day 1 without waiting for some DRM crap to check online everything was ok.  This game just works and makes you want to keep playing and playing. With the availability of mods on day 1 the user community is already adding great content and expanding the game every day.  I highly recommend people buy this and just enjoy a large open playable, simulated city building game.  EA hang your head in shame!

Finally a City Builder that actually manages to combine the management/design factors of games like SimCity 2000 and the aesthetic power of games like Cities XL.  I get the feeling that the developers of this game played a lot of Cities XL and Simcity 2013 and then sat down in a big group and said 'You know those really annoying and silly things those games do? Let's NOT do those.'  It's not perfect, there's some things that can be irritating, but not unbearable, and they are so vastly outweighed by the positive aspects that they don't really matter anyway. The gameplay is well balanced, with income in the early game making it a challenge to inexperienced players, but once you get the hang of designing areas and supplying them with requirements, your town will level up and you get a new set of requirements, which keeps pushing the game forward well.  The opportunity to buy new land means the Cities can reach massive sizes, though I haven't got to that sort of stage yet and can't tell you how well the game plays there, but I've had no issues with performance of the game up to this point.  All in all, a fun, engaging City-Builder with a lot of character, some nice new ideas to help you manage your city and keep your citizens happy, plenty of content and exceptional mod support that keeps that content growing.

This is a real slap in the face to the corporative chauvinism that drives game design in big greedy publishing firms like EA or Ubisoft. This kind of 'Think Tank' arrogance drove Maxis to it's grave. In the end, EA didn't get the last word. I don't know what their agenda was but let the lesson be learnt.   Colossal Order took Simcity 2013, cleaned it of it's debilitating afflictions, perfectionned it and re-released it under a new identity.  There is not much that have not been already said about the game. It's well optimized, the traffic simulation is excellent, you can make pretty big cities, there are Metros, Busses, Trains and Highways. There are districts that you can draw the limits to and add specific policies to. There is also a dynamic water simulation that is rather cool but not that impressive. The game feels like a finished and well balanced product for the price. The end product is a very decent City builder with a lot of potential. For now, I can't think of any other City builder that is as advanced or as good.  And that leads to the shortcommings.  As good as it is, it falls short on more than a few level. First of all, regarding the zoning and policies. I really like the idea of districts, but the list of policies and city rules that you can pass is very short. There is so much potential here. Why not let me ban bars in a district to reduce crime, or promote art galleries or small workshops. You can ban Hi-rise buildings but why not choose a particular architectural style? Or build commercial pedestrian only roads.   Regarding transportation, I would have loved to see Bicycle lanes. Being able to set a public biking service.  Why is there no aspect in the game regarding homelessness? And maybe adopt district policies to drive homeless people out, or to shelter them and so on. Something to give personnality to your city.  Lastly, why isn't there 'mixed' zoning? As in, comercial on the first floor, residential on the upper floors. You know, like in every big cities.   Well I guess these are my main complaints, but i'm just happy that the game is what it is right now. I completely recommend it. Let's hope some updates will bring new interesting features.   The steam page also states 'Extensive modding support' so let's see what interesting thing can be done by the community.

Let's make this cut & dry. We all know why we came here to investigate and play this game. Want my 2 cents?  Succeeds and even exceeds where both Simcity and Cities XXL have failed to meet the expections of both new and seasoned players of this simulation genre. Gives you the real feel that you're building, managing, and expanding a truly lively, gigantic, beautifully-designed city. It's not just about plopping down buildings or zones. There are serious, 'real-time' variables at work affecting the overall environment, and ever-changing. The combination of environmental sub-physics simulation and near flawless traffic flow simulation are enough alone to make you admire the wondrous world that Paradox have put together for us.  Priced at $30 upon launch, this is something you cannot and should not miss; for you will not regret your next purchase!

Everything Simcity (2013) was supposed to be, this is. As noted by a few other reviewers, there are a couple minor issues/annoyances, such as the lack of a day/night cycle, but nothing that keeps you from enjoying the game.   One thing I think was particularly well done is the pacing of the unlocks. Everything seems to become available just as you need it, usually anyway. Little things like that show just how much playtesting was done prior to release.   Also, if you didn't already know, Paradox sent copies to a multitude of streamers before release, so they could show the game off. Strategy and Simulation games have always been my favorite, but this game is seriously above and beyond.  The graphics are pretty great. At a distance you can see every car, moving and parked. As you zoom in you can see each individual person. Even animals.  Click on just about anything and a box pops up with loads of information. A person will show their name, where they are headed, where they live, where they work. Vehicles tell you where they are headed, where they are from. Even animals tell what they are doing. My very first game I zoomed in and a seagull flew into my view. And I clicked on it. And it told me its name was seagull and that it was flying.  EVERYTHING IS SIMULATED. Seriously everything. I don't have quite the greatest computer (3.6ghz dual core processor, 1GB GDDR5 graphics card) but it ran perfectly all the way up to a city size of around 19,000 or so... and even then I hardly noticed the lag, only when I moved my view.  The road building is incredible. Completely free-form if you want, or more control if that's your style. One minor complaint: you can't build intersections very close together. It has a hard time putting two intersections within one section of road. (But then again that's probably for the best)  Traffic Simulation is great. As more and more roads are built and changed, the traffic changes patterns to find the fastest/best route. In my latest game I built a roundabout at the end of the highway. Trucks from the industrial area were clogging the intersection so i made an on/off ramp that bypasses the roundabout. The moment I finished building the ramps, trucks were already using it.  Two words: Water. Physics. Rivers actually flow. Build a dam and watch the water level in front of it slowly rise the entire length of the river.  All of the building tools are extremely easy to use. UI is intuitive. Sometimes lags when you try to click the bulldozer so you end up upgrading the road you wanted to demolish... but otherwise good.  Other cons I found: -Sometimes building angled or curved roads near existing buildings will change the zoning squares, deleting said buildings. -Sometimes traffic doesn't use all available lanes (But that happens in real life I suppose) -Also check out other reviews for things that don't bother me  Suggestions for devs: It would be nice if water and electricity funding showed production and usage values (rather than switching to each build panel to see if a 5% or so boost was enough)  Overall: Great Graphics Runs well even on lower level computers Simulates literally everything Water Physics If you like the genre: its a definite buy.

Fast forward to today, I can say this game is incredible. The developers really know what people want out of a city simulation game and delivered that perfectly. I've spent 31.7 hours so far playing this game, and that is just over the weekend. I'm kind of bummed I have to go back to work today and can't spend the whole day tinkering and growing my megacity.   There are a few quirks here and there as are to be expected with a newly released game, but nothing game breaking. The intensive mod support for this game really makes it stand out and just a few days into release there are already so many awesome mods available.  10/10 would definitely recommend. Just be sure you're prepared to lose several days to playing.

A very fun and addictive, if sometimes frustrating city builder.   Pros: -extensive modding community -very easy to get into for people new to the genre -wide variety of maps, and the size is very large (not like Sim City where the map is ridiculously tiny) -graphics look great, especially with the tilt-lens effect -many different ways to build your city -interface is very user-friendly and easy to understand  Cons:  -bus line system is a bit confusing, game doesn't really explain well how it works -some issues with optimization, gets frame skips and crashes a lot even on my high end PC -the game doesn't have as large of a variety of buildings as it seems like it should -it can be difficult at times to tell why your city's happiness level is decreasing  Despite the issues it has, Cities Skylines is excellent. This is one of those games that will keep you up late at night going 'Okay, I'll just put a few more buildings here, and then I'll stop...' and just when you think you're done, you'll want to come back and play more. Overall 9/10.

Many people make the comparison between this game and SimCity 2013, and all say the same: SimCity simply can't compete with this masterpiece. The guys at EA and Maxis (in memorium) should be embarrassed that a company of thirteen employees can make a game superior to theirs in every single way. Sure, I played SimCity two years ago. I looked past its faults and took it for what it is. After play Cities: Skylines, I will NEVER open SimCity again, and neither will you.  You don't need me to tell you the details of what this game does better than SimCity, just watch some videos on YouTube (Keralis has a good C:S series). Watching videos is a good way to decide whether the game is for you and getting inspiration and tips and tricks for building your cities.  In conclusion: Is this game a masterpiece? Yes. Does it blow every other city sim out of the water? Yes. Should you buy it? I'm not going to tell you how to spend your money, so probably (the price is incredibly fair for the hours of enjoyment you will get out of it. I'm at 50 hours while writing this, which is almost as low as 50p an hour).  tl;dr: Yes, yes, a thousand times yes.

Traffic patters. Traffic patterns all day. Traffic patterns all night. I eat, breathe, and sleep traffic patterns. I find myself thinking geometrically at times I probably shouldn't. I want to be a city planner. In fact, I am a city planner.  And this game will make you feel the same. You won't drive down the street the same way again. With that being said, this game clearly made an impression on me. It's likely the best city simulator on the market today. With loads of different building types, zones, policies, industries, and transport avenues, there's a ton to micromanage and develope. This game will defintly keep you busy for hours.  The only drawback I found was that cities max out around 200,000 population, which isn't all that hard to reach if you plan your roads accordingly (without implementing mods). I also found it to be rather easy at times, but perhaps that's just because I think of myself as a Domestic King, but that's more of an innnerself issue I need to figure out.  Buy this game, and wonder why your actual city developers chose to build the way they did - cause it won't make sense to you anymore.

This game is superb. Where to begin? I think one of my favourite aspects is the realism of the water physics. I built a dam, in the wrong place as it turned out, and it flooded my industrial area. I deleted the dam, and most of the water went, but because of the lay of the land two little lakes formed. They are slowly diminishing, but it was quite something to watch, even if it did require me to rebuild my highway and industry....  Building roads in this is also a dream (and possibly a nightmare if, like me, you accidentally start the game with the traffic driving one the *wrong* side of the road, thus confusing the hell out of me). You can end up with some seriously cool looking junctions and highway slip roads.   The assest editor is an added bonus. You can practice making your fancy junctions without fear you are neglecting your city. You can also build your own parks, buildings and more, that you can then use in game.   As for the game play itself? It constently keeps you wanting to play more. You aim for population levels which give you bonuses and the chance to expand, whilst juggling residential, commercial and industrial needs, building public transport and planning for future expansion, all whilst ensuring power and water are connected properly, and noise pollution is not too high. There is so much to do, and it is so engrossing, that I warn you only get it if you have the time to spare. Once you start playing, people will not be seeing you for a while, your other commitments may suffer. You have been warned!

I have been looking forward to this game for months, and after the first hour or so of play  Cities: Skylines  felt like a keeper. Now that I have well over seventy hours of game time accumulated, I'm convinced that this is one game that I'll be playing for years to come.  It has been said many times in many ways, but this really is what  SimCity 2013  should have been.  Cities  manages to capture a lot of the magic from the fantastic  SimCity 4 . I'm really enjoying the building process and am enjoying expanding with transit and larger areas. The 'district' feature is promising and the game looks great; it also runs well on my older PC. There are no doubt things that can be tweaked and improved over time, and new features to add, but this game was in great shape right from launch. I'm really impressed with how quickly and effortlessly the modding community has embraced the game and the vast array of tweaks and tricks that have been developed already.   Cities: Skylines  is definitely well worth the purchase, and it is no surprise that the game has already sold over one million copies. Just buy it!  EDIT: Two months, 100+ hours on the game, still loving it. There's a new update today. one word: TUNNELS! (Oh yes, Euro-style buildings, bug fixes, great dev support - did I mention the tunnels?)

Garbage simulator 2015. 11/10 - would bury my city under filth again.   Seriously though, wonderful city builder and really addictive sim - the best since Simcity 4. It's very easy to start up a city and to start understanding the basics, and I've suffered the 'Civilization' effect several times, thinking I'd been playing an hour when I'd actually been staring at the screen, following traffic patterns for 3 hours.   The Steam Workshop support really elevates this to a higher level. You can find everything from McDonalds to the Better Call Saul billboard to the freaking Death Star in there, and add it to your game in a click. There are also numerous mods that can change everything. The Workshop support alone makes this one worth playing if you're a fan of the genre.   HOWEVER, as fun as it is, this one's extremely traffic dependant. You have to really work to make sure your traffic flows properly. And as I said above....garbage. My god, my cities and their garbage. Your trucks won't go where you want them. The landfill will be full before you realize it's even close to being so. Emptying the landfill takes hours of real-life time, and you can only do so if you have another garbage facility to move it to. It's almost like a statement about the wastefulness of our species or something, and while I appreciate the 'sim' side of the game, the garbage mechanic does detract from the fun somewhat. There are mods that can help with it, but they block acheivements. Once I master garbage, I'll master the game. I'm sure of it.   If you ever played Simcity, Simcity 2000, Simcity 3000, or Simcity 4 and want something to bring back that magic...pick this one up. It's worth every penny.

Cities: Skylines. More like Traffic: Highlights, amirite?  No, seriously, though, this is hands-down the absolute best city-building simulator I've ever played. It's missing some features, but mods cover most of those (things like fire-spreading). They've announced an upcoming expansion to the game that also has a day-night cycle with different behavior, and such, so that will be a major improvement to the game, for sure. My only gripes would be maybe to tweak the traffic AI, just a little; sometimes, the pathing of the cars is bizarre, and makes no rational sense beyond 'my AI says this is the fastest way to my destination even though there's a direct cutaway to there that's ultimately faster and no the person writing this is not at all bitter about some of the traffic back-ups.'  tl;dr: Best SimCity 2015. 10/10

I had to take a break from my 12 hours straight to give a review of this fantastic game.  Cities Skylines is the best cities sim game i have ever played, of course there are some issues but the pros far outweigh the cons.  Some things that stand out to me: - First the zoning is such a great tool, paint along the roads and the building type get built, its quick, easy, and a huge time saver. - Each sim you see has his own path, his own job, house, car, and you can click on him and watch him go through the city. - The unique buildings. - The way they set up the traffic so you will get traffic jams but they will only get so out of hand as to not gridlock the entire city.  A few things that could be changed: -There is no night cycles so the traffic is always steady. It would be nice to have rush hours and slow times. - The budgeting is good but it would be nice to be able to budget each building seperately. - Mass transit is a little confusing when you get more than 3 seperate lines. - The building skins repeat ALOT. - Some of the messages from buildings ie: To few services, are to vague.  If you havent bought this game, what are you waiting for?  Fantastic game!  Now back for another 12 hours!

Cities: Skylines is the best city builder I have played.  Skylines provides plenty of creative challenges in efficiency and design without forcing you to break your train of thought. Your city will have problems (mostly your poor planning), but they rarely need to be dealt with promptly. The tools provided are well implemented. You can fight traffic, instead of the interface.  The Skylines team kept a great focus on the scope of the game. You won't be burdened by micromanagement, but there is still a satisfactory depth. The details are there, for fluff and functionality. You can select a pedestrian and follow her on her journey through your transportation network to find clues on where you've gone wrong.  If you are itching for a city builder, play City: Skylines.

Having written this review after the initial rush, I hope there will be room for both positive and negative views. At this point, I am well into the game and its myriad of mods and features. The obvious point of comparison remains the (somewhat failed) reboot of the SimCity, for better or for worse.  Both games remain focused on the RCI indicator, a series of bars indicating the rise and fall of demand for development of Residiential, Commercial, and Industrial zones. However, Cities: Skylines is at heart a traffic simulator, unsurprising when one considers the history of the software company. I believe that the original SimCity that came out when I was a kid was simularly a traffic simulator, in much the same way that another Maxis gem, SimTower, was an elevator simulator. However, players will notice that much more attention has been paid to the traffic simulation than to other areas of the game.  Where SimCity focused on a sense of 'progress' and 'rewards,' while always dangling the carrot of a destructive God-Mode, Cities: Skylines is much more laidback. If you want to destroy your city, you'll have more success taking the route of the insane mayor than the path of some prehistoric demon-lord. Cities:Skylines offers no insta-volcanoes, robot-attacks, or click-and-drag tornadoes -- instead, you could remove the sewage treatment from your city. Or remove the roads connecting your town with the outside world. Or destroy the power plant.  The effectiveness of such mundane 'disasters' showcases the strength of Cities: Skylines -- interconnectedness. The game is about the tiny changes that constantly occur, with or without your input. Whatever you did to fix that last problem will lie dormant for a week, or a month, or a year. But that quick-fix is going to come back, in a big way. For example: because you needed to increase the traffic capacity for your industrial zones, you built a hastily surveyed hiway connecting your city borders to your job-creators. Some years later, that well-meaning traffic fix is creating all kinds of havoc, keeping your trucks from using the lovely rail/super-hiway ring-system around your city.  And that's a problem more easily solved than most!

Ever wonder why construction in your city takes about six months longer than you think it should? What about why on/off ramps seem to go nowhere productive and lead you right into speeding traffic when the turn clearly says 45? How about what happens if you don't have a fire station on every block if you put any one way roads in your city?  Then prepare yourself for the ultimate simulation. Cities: Skylines solves all of these age old questions. Basically taking everything Sim City ♥♥♥♥ed up and doing it right, while also making some city planning tools entirely unrealistic (looking at you stop and go traffic in an open and unpopulated area).  10/10 would destroy residents living somewhere for ten year's home to build skyscrapers to keep the rest of the people happy, again.

The vanilla version is bit too easy/sandbox, but the mod community builds well on top of very solid foundations. This game clearly has a lot of longevity in it - I can see myself jumping in for 10-20 hours every quarter or two for quite some time to build new cities will all the new official/modded content coming out. Excellent value for money.

Pros:  -Much smoother and more fun than Sim City. -You can rename pretty much everything in the game, allowing you to create entire neighborhoods full of serial killers and 1970s porn stars. -Pacing is great. Just when you start to feel a little tedium, you level up and get new stuff. -It's not a gritty WW2 first person shooter. -I don't think I've seen even one zombie; a true rarity for any game made after 2001.  Cons:  I only have three complaints about Cities: Skylines.   -Building roads can be a bit frustrating ('Space already occupied!'), though there are plenty of mods out there that help with annoyances like pillars getting in the way.  -Once I hit the 150,000 citizens mark, I lose interest. -You can't give your serial killers or porn stars mustaches.

A no-brainer, just buy this game. Of more than a hundred games that I own, this game definitely ranks high on the enjoyment/price ratio. That is, if you're into city builder/management game.

I get the feeling that the developers of this game played a lot of Cities XL and Simcity 2013 and then sat down in a big group and said 'You know those really annoying and silly things those games do? Let's NOT do those.'  It's not perfect, there's some things that can be irritating, but not unbearable, and they are so vastly outweighed by the positive aspects that they don't really matter anyway. The gameplay is well balanced, with income in the early game making it a challenge to inexperienced players, but once you get the hang of designing areas and supplying them with requirements, your town will level up and you get a new set of requirements, which keeps pushing the game forward well.  The opportunity to buy new land means the Cities can reach massive sizes, though I haven't got to that sort of stage yet and can't tell you how well the game plays there, but I've had no issues with performance of the game up to this point.  All in all, a fun, engaging City-Builder with a lot of character, some nice new ideas to help you manage your city and keep your citizens happy, plenty of content and exceptional mod support that keeps that content growing.

Edit : After playing over 30 hours now, I've discovered a flaw that eventually breaks the game. 'Death waves' as they are apparently known, are a problem as soon as you get over about 30k people, but when you get nearer to 100k, they can cause massive drops in population, that aren't recovered before the next one hits, inevitably crushing your economy. I had one earlier today (10/10 2015) that resulted in a population drop of over 40k in about 30 minutes. It was rediculous, and its ruining the fun of the game. Currently there are no mods that seem to actually solve the problem. This game was a 10/10 for me. But after dealing with repeated, city crippling death waves, I would rate this game a 7/10. Still a great game, but this is a terrible design flaw.  /// End edit ///   This is the game I've been waiting for since SimCity 4. SimCity 4 has served me very well for many years, but finally, I think I can put it to rest and move forward to a new city builder. It's not perfect by any means, no game ever is. But this game is essentially everything I wanted Simcity (2013) to be. Everything it should have been.  I've put 15 hours in it so far, in a very short time. And if I wasn't so tired right now, I'd be putting even more into it. Many of the road building options are things I longed for in Simcity, like being able to custimize interchanges (down to making one exit and over pass and the other a tunnel) make roads into tunnels where ever I want.   Earlier I had a death wave, which nearly crushed my economy, and it really shook things up for a bit while I tried to stabilize everything. And with the ability to do almost what ever I want with the highways and roads, left me spending around an hour just trying to figure out a bypass/on/offramp system to free traffic up in an area I'd devoloped too heavily. I wound up with 2 off ramps to different roads, and 2 tunnels bypassing the whole area. And I had a blast doing it.  Obviously, compared to simcity 4 with 10 years worth of mods, its a little light on content. but what it does have is excellent and enjoyable. So if you've burnt out on SC4, but don't want to build tiny 'cities' on SC(2013), this is the game for you.  It also has a huge amount of mods already out there, so I don't think it will be behind SC4 in that department for long.

I am,  by no means , a veteran of city-building games.  My cities are messy. My citizens are undoubtedly confused. I slap down zones and buildings based on wants, not needs. My compulsion to draw symmetrically is a handicap. I cannot get those accursed hydro plants to work. My mind cannot comprehend the criteria for unlocking certain buildings.  I am,  by all means , enthralled by Cities: Skylines.  =-= =-= =-= =-= =-= =-=  It is a rare ocassion when a game will allow even the most clueless of players to succeed. I suspect that it would be safe to assume that most of Skylines' current players have at least some background with other city-builders, whether it be with the classic SimCity titles, the not-so-classic SimCity 2013 or more modern examples like Cities X(X)L.  My own glancing knowledge of SimCity 2000, 3000 and 2013 will have certainly helped with the transition into Skylines, but it still felt like an entirely new experience. However, the game does extremely well in explaining its mechanics and guiding an unskilled hand, providing tutorial messages and prompts only when relevant.  Cities: Skylines assumes nothing of you, short of some common sense and logical thinking. Put yourself in the shoes of your citiy's citizens. Where do they need to go? How can they get there? What do they need to live comfortably (or uncomfortably, as it may be)? Whatever your solution, it's likely that the game will allow you to execute it. With that said, the core mechanics are not particularly difficult to understand.  Skylines, for the most part, follows the formula established by SimCity 3000 and onwards. Build roads, place zones, construct utilities, and you're pretty much good to go. As your city grows, throw in education, police, firefighters and dealing with land values to develop further. Soon after, you're dealing with public transportation, taxes, extra policies and perhaps working towards the lofty goal of building a wonder-like monument.  All of this may sound slightly intimidating to newcomers, but Skylines never forces you to approach the game with all of these things in mind. It allows you to do whatever you want, provided you have the funds to do to (there is a built-in money cheat you can use if you want). Certainly, the game will prod you with brief messages to bring matters to your attention, but you're under no obligation to do anything that it tells you to in order to build a working city.  My time with this game, a paltry eight hours as of writing, is exponentially less than other reviewers, but I can safely tell you that Cities: Skylines is not something that you will regret playing, assuming you have any interest at all in the genre. There are still numerous aspects that I am yet to discover and play with, but that really only adds to the desire to keep going.  =-= =-= =-= =-= =-= =-=  Note: Skylines is famous for its modding support, but I am yet to explore the possibilities. Therefore, it has not factored into my opinion.

Being someone who never took the time to seriously sit-down with a city builder, Cities: Skylines is still a blast for beginners like myself. While I did dabble around a bit with previous SimCity titles, all the way back with the original, I would always just goof around for a few minutes before leaving the game. I'm so glad I gave this game a chance, because what a fun time it's been already!  Building residential, commercial, industrial, and even office zones, the whole idea to is just make a city! There's really no 'right' way to build, though there are 'better' ways. Still, finding those ways by yourself through learning is a rewarding experience. Want to make a small farming community? You got it! Going for a more mid-sized town? Go for gold! You want the magnificent skyscrapers that reach the clouds? Why, certainly! It's all up to you.  You're able to freely select different areas of your choosing, and set them as districts. With each district, you can control their own policies and laws. Ever wanted to legalize recreational drug use? You can totally do that. if that's not your thing, maybe you wish to provide free smoke detectors? Each policy comes with it's own benefits and maybe even some slight drawbacks. A great addition that keeps your city running exactly how you want it.   A very wonderful feature of Skylines is the support of mods. The game's Steam Workshop already has a slew of custom things for download. Buildings, parks, roads...you name it, and the workshop likely has it. Expect a whole bunch more user-created content as days go by! It doesn't stop as just physical items, either. Mods like camera controls with more freedom, better tree placement tools, getting rid of the Twitter-esque ticker known as 'Chirpy', auto-save, color filters...the list goes on. Tweak your game like crazy!  Still not sure? Not interested in actually managing expenses and unlocking content as you play? Colossal Order has you covered. The game comes pre-equipped with a few mods made by the devs. Two of them letting you play as a full sandbox mode, being 'Unlimited Money' and 'All Unlocks.' But perhaps you're more of a go-getter, and desire challenge. They have a 'Hard Mode' mod as well! Everything is more expensive, so keep your finances strong!   There's just so much more I'd love to say and continue to gush, but I'm getting the itch to go back and play more! For $30, you're getting way more than your money's worth. With outstanding mod support, the replayability is unlimited. Oh, did I mention there's also a map editor for making your own regions, too? Because there totally is. Go make a city based on your a real city, or around a (inactive) volcano!   Bottom line, this game seriously rocks. Why are you still here? Go click the 'Add to Cart' button, already.

Very enjoyable game to play. I like to sit back with some relaxing music of my own and just play this game for a few hours. I have never played a Sims game so I can't compare Cities to that series. However, I did grow up playing the Roller Coaster Tycoon series and to me this game is very reminiscent of that.  The steam workshop in this game really helps with the longevity of the game. It keeps things fresh and really allows you to personalize your city.  The only issues that I have ever had are:   1. The game can be confusing to new players, the lack of instruction is almost as if CO expects you to have played the first Cities game.  However, guides can very easily be found on Youtube as well as right here on Steam.  2. The extremely long load times when your city starts to get up in the 80,000+ range in terms of population.  However, it's expected since the city at that point is fairly large, and whatever you have placed in the world from the workshop only makes the load times longer.   3. Corrupt maps when you delete some buildings/monuments from your world that you have downloaded from the workshop.  This is less of a problem for me now, when the game first came out it was a big issue and I have recently found myself being able to go back to my corrupt maps and begin rebuilding! Huge ++  4. The frame drop in larger cities is almost unbearable.  Again, this is expected since it can be very crowded in some places. It's a personal issue for me since I have a habit of building metropoleis full of workshop skyscrapers. I'm sure the problem would be at least a little less noticeable in cities that are more spread out.  All in all, I think this game is well worth whatever price you happen to find it at. I haven't purchased the After Dark DLC yet, but I do plan to do so now that I am getting back into this game with my old cities functioning properly again!

GREAT city-cuilder. They nailed it.  In this game full of rich landscape visuals and charming music, you get to build the cities of your dreams. Really, there is so much freedom in this game, you can do almost anything you can imagine, reasonably speaking. The in-game toolset is very easy to learn. The interface is a bit tricky. They put some buttons right on the edge of the screen, and it is difficult to click them without edge-scrolling away from where you are working. If you are on a mac and have hotspots setup, its even worse. The people are quite easy to keep happy and the money is not difficult to make. I would probably say 9/10 of the challenge in this game is in planning your city infrastructure. You may get a city setup and get 10k people moving it and think you've done a good job, and then you get traffic jams, and businesses start abandoning the city because nobody is getting to work, and garbage piles up because the children are not getting to school, and then everyon gets sick, and the hospitals get over-crowded, and crime goes up because nobody has a job, and your whole world falls apart, all because you didn't plan ahead when you build that intersection in the middle of town. It may sound frustrating, but actually even failures are quite fun.  The default maps are mostly really lame, but the game includes a fully featured map editor so you can build your own, or play on a map made by someone else on the workshop. The map editor is a bit anoying because of how the volume and behavior of the water is simulated. Rivers are kind of a big deal in this game and to make one, you can't just cut a trench in the ground and fill it with water and decide which direction it should flow, you have to actually create an inlet where the water will come from, and wait for the simulation to push all the water around so that the river actually moves. I let the simulation run for about 1.5 hours on a map I made (while I worked on other parts of the map) and it still wasn't completely hammered out. But, if you make your rivers/water areas first, you can let the simulation run them while you finish up everything else.   In addition to maps, the game includes asset editors for making custom buildings, vehichles, intersection designs, etc. I couldn't figure out the building editor, but designing intersection presets is way more fun than I would have expected. The roads can be tricky to work with because of how they try to snap to everything nearby, but when done carefully, you can do some really cool stuff with it.  If you are familiar with SimCity4, you may recall having to set the budget for a facility to avoid wasting money on under-used services. One thing you will quickly notice in this game is that you set a budget for a service category rather than each facility. It can be annoying because your elementary school is over-funded while your highschool is under-funded and you only get one budget for all education services. But, it gives you more of a challenge to place facilities strategically so that they all balance out as much as possible.  There is no sort of selection-tool in the game. When you have no service category active, you can examine the status of any building by clicking on it, but when editing roads you can only make them and demolish them. There is no way to plan them out ahead of time and then let it all happen. So if you do it wrong, you just have to accept that the money you spent on that project is gone and you'll have to try again. It incentivises care and forethought, but I definately think the game would be improved with more selection-oriented controls and a way to plan construction before having the spend all your money on it.  The game has a lot of special, unlockable buildings to embelesh your city with. Some of them are neat, but some of them are silly. For example, a solar array that makes noise pollution. As if solar panels could possibly sit in the sun any quieter. Not to mention the space elevator! I suppose every city and every map must be on the earth's equator. Surely the game designers realize you can't just build a space elevator anywhere you want. But, you could look at it as things to RP with I guess. Maybe an equatorial space elevator city is what you want? Best of all though, the one thing this game does not seem to have which many others do, is frikin chruches! I finally get to build a city where the game doesn't throw some religious crap in my face every once in a while. That alone makes it that much more special.  I know this may look like a rather negative review, but it really is a good game. It is not without its hangups and I want to be fair and mention them, but I recommend it for anyone who likes city-builders and stuff like that. If you've never played a city builder and are wondering if it's worth giving it a try, this might be the perfect game to get your toes wet.

It's my 1st pre-ordered game, and I have been playing it since launched. It's nice, it's awesome, it's heavily inspired and influenced by the famous SimCity but there are still rooms for improvement. Based on the core game:  Pros: - Huge map size.  - Can play without Internet connection. - Lots of mods since day 1. - Built-in Assets and Maps Editor.  Cons (hopefully CO will fix them through future updates): - Gravel road SHOULD be the 1st to have instead of being an 'unlockable' tool.  - Base game color is a bit dull, and buildings can be very repetitive IF without mod contents. - Traffic AI is as bad as in SC2013. Cims will line up on a single lane on a multi-lane road/highway even though their next exit is 100KM away. Cims are polite drivers and no queue jumpers...and this including emergency service vehicles...lol! - No modular buildings. I personally think that SC2013 has way better building features. Think of its University building. Damn I love that! - Lack of specialized industries. It only has Oil, Ore, Forest, and Farm in general. However, while Oil and Ore are not renewable but they deplete way too fast. Who wants to setup an oil digger for only couple months worth of resources?  - Lack of detailed info on Income/Expenses. It would be great if we can know the profit and loss from goods export and tourism. - Lack of micromanagement game play.   Overall, although the base game play can be lacked of depth, it's still fun to play, it's quite relax, you don't have to really worry about money except in the very beginning, and it definitely fits your bill if all you want is to fill up a big map. The best part, mods are available since day 1, and it just keeps growing. Hopefully we will get more DLCs in the future. More specialized industries? Tourism? Casino? BIG modular theme park?   SC2013 was great when it comes to in game contents as well as its game music. My wish? SC2013 contents + Cities Skylines. That, will be perfect.

This game is one of the best city builders out there. I havent put too much time in the game. But I have a 20,000 population city and is making a ton of money. Here are a few tips to help get you started:  1. Make use of all of the land possible. This means you can zone all of the land inside of the square or rectange of road. Maintaining roads cost a lot. This made me restart my city a few times.  2. Raise your tax to 11%. I know it sounds like a lot lol but this is the highest you can go without the cims complaining.  3. Lower your budget a bit. You can lower every budget panel to 75% exept power and electricity. You can keep that at 100%.  4. Do not use districts untill a much higher level or not use them at all. Using districts cost a ton of money so if you ask me, dont use them.  5. Make a lot of garbage dumps. But do not place them next to residential areas. Make them somewhat spread around your city.  Hope this guide helped you start your first city! This game is really fun so I want to make sure you get the most out of this game!!
