Talk about attention to detail... I was really impressed with this game from the start. I'm a casual gamer, I don't like challenges and I also do not like to pay attention. A few hours into the game I expected it to start getting more demanding, like my citizens are pissy because they want more of something. I was wrong, the game progresses as fast as you want it to, which is totally fine by me. I'm not going to jump all over the pluses in this game, but I did want to point out the fact you don't feel pressured playing. Also, it took me until I went into First Person View to relize the depth the developers put into the game. Traffics a big part, of course, the flow of traffic. But the devs went above and beyond to fine detail the suspension of vehicles going around corners. Another sweet attention to detail is the fire fighters. Yes, they show up jump out of their truck and start spraying the building.. But, the fire fighters that enter the building have on resperators and oxygen tanks.. I mean, holy ♥♥♥♥.. Detail that isn't really mean't to be seen up close, is detailed.

This, everyone, is my favorite game EVER!!! What very few limitations it has, such as a little lag, and a wee bit of aggervating sloping concepts, Is miniscule to the good things, like accurate city growth and traffic. CitiesXL, CitiesXXL, and SimCity must be quivering in their boots (I don't think I said that right). It is absolutely amazing, and with DLC and updates frequent, You have alot to look foward to!   Now, on to the DLC.   At the time of this writing, there are 2 major DLCs, 'After Dark' and 'Snowfall'   After Dark in my oppinion is the best one. As well as an obvious day/night cycle, it adds a variaty of beauty to the game, aswell as some new features, such as leisure specialization and new unique buildings.   Snowfall could have many things improved. #1, Seasons. At the moment, there is only 2 options, you get rain, or you get snow. Even in boreal/temperate biomes there is no seasons. #2, Eternal Winter. This kinda goes with #1, but if you decide to play in a winter map, it is permanent. There is no summer. It's kinda like playing on a game where your building a city from Disney's 'Frozen.' #3, Heating. So already there is a busy network under your city. Metros, Trains, Tunnels, and Water. So who wants to spend another 5 hours putting in a city-wide heating system? But at least there are trams...   In conclusion, Cities: Skylines is still awesome and my favorite computer game! I highly reccomend this to any person who likes city simulations!    Cities: Skylines: 100000/10  Cities: Skylines with After Dark: 200000/10  Cities: Skylines with A.D. and Snowfall: 8/10  ~Cortwade

As an avid player of both Cities in Motion, and Cities in Motion 2, Colossal Order's two previous games, I was excitied for Cities: Skylines. I'm not going to waste your time by talking about it is the savior we need in an era of SimCity (A game thats good enough despite the hate it gets) and Cities XXL (an outright scam, and not even that fun of a game). It is better than all those games.   It has a lot in common with SimCity, but also adopts a lot from its Cities in Motion heritage, such as districts and road design. The larger cities and greater freedom you have already make it better than SC2013, but the zoning design really exceeded my expectations. I was expecting something similar to CitiesXL, but the zoning methodology works really well, especially with non-perpendicular road designs.   One of my favorite features in the game are pathways and trails, which act as roads for pedestrians. They work really well and reduce traffic at pedestrian crossings - they also look really cool and work exactly as they are intended to.   While the game is far from perfect, I look forward to seeing the mods that others can make to improve the game, and the future updates to the game. I really enjoyed my first few hours with the game and look forward to what the game will do in the future.  As a loyal CO customer, I can tell you from firsthand experience that there will probably be ~$40 worth of $1-5 dollar DLC which add individual buildings, gameplay features, or map features. They don't really do large expansion packs, but expect a bunch of these smaller ones. Many of these may offer a gameplay advantage, but it doesn't really matter too much on single player. Additionally, they have been known to make free DLCs for the other two games, so expect some free updates in the future too.

Cities: Skylines is a tremendously fun sandbox that allows you to design your own near-future city, build tremendously horrific road systems, and inflict them on your simulated citizens. You can name everything that you can click on, then watch as buildings send out delivery trucks to transport goods from the Butter and Sardine Emporium to the Shoddy Workplace Practices Transit Station. Your citizens will get sick, die, even yell at you in the virtual Twitter analogue.  Throw in mod support out of the box, in-game editors for maps and items, a dedicated fan base, and it's no wonder there are ~25,000 items in the Steam Workshop for the game after just a few weeks. I can't wait to see how it looks after a more robust toolset evolves.  There are a few downsides--some of the mechanics are a bit obtuse, it's already difficult to weed out the good mods from the bad, and the game really needs a few disasters to shake things up. The original SimCity had fires, earthquakes, tornadoes, and giant monsters, I don't think an outbreak of grey goo nanites or a rocket mishap would be too far out of the question. Still, Cities: Skylines is amazingly fun and you should buy it. Now!

It's easier to start with the bad things about this game because there are so few of them. For the moment, the biggest problem is that the traffic simulation sucks. It's unrealistic and results in a huge line of cars in one lane with the other lanes remaining empty. Fortunately, it can be worked around with strategic use of traffic circles/roundabounts.  That said, this game is amazing. It's beautiful, the non-traffic mechanics are solid and easy to understand. The interface is clear and never obstructive. The tools for creating new assets are great. It can be difficult to create interesting and unique road intersections while keeping them functional, but a little practice with the road tools and it comes as easily to me as it could be. The addition of water simulation is really cool, but it only comes into practice with laying down hydroelectric dams.  The developers put in a ton of mod support (enough that someone could create a mod that maliciously affects your computer, so watch out) and they're in constant contact with the community. They're also adding new features as time goes by, so I'm really looking forward to that.  Features currently missing from the game that you might consider 'standard' include disasters, tunnels, day/night cycles, and weather. As of this review, tunnels are being added soon and disasters will probably show up eventually as well, if not modded in by someone cool before then.  Look, if you're a fan of city builders, just get it. It's great. I love it. You'll love it, too.

EA Maxis eat your heart out.  With the disastrous stewardship that EA Maxis unfortunately perpetuated on the once-beloved SimCity series over the past decade, the market has been ripe for a new developer to take the crown for best city building sim, and I think that CO just did.  This is already the game that SimCity (5) should have been and more, and it's still in Early Access. I normally don't touch Early Access titles, though after hearing so many good things about this game, I just had to give it a go, and I was not disappointed.  If, like me, you have been frustrated over the years by EA Maxis's obtrusive DRM, demands for persistent internet connections, and general butthattery, give this game a try. You'll be glad that you did.  Now I can finally uninstall SimCity 4.  About the only negative thing I can say about this game is that out of the box, it likes to run my ATI card at full throttle 100% of the time (i.e. wasting a lot of power and unnecessarily generating a bunch of heat) unless I tweak some command line options and tell my drivers to force VSync. Hopefully the developers will be fixing this issue before release, as this nearly turned me off from even starting to play.

An excellent spiritual successor (of sorts) to the Simcity series. I am a series veteran -- Simcity 1 to current -- and I can state that the game is worthwhile. There are of course some things that could be added or revised, but the game is worth the money.

This game filled the massive, gaping hole that the last SimCIty game left in my heart (being a diehard SimCity fan since childhood, since their first NES game).  I have only a few very minor, very insigificant (and easily ignored) criticisms: the building names could use more variety (example: so many 'Ice Cube Factories' and 'Box Factories' in the low-density industrial zones!).  Same issue with the 'Chirper'. I wish it would tweet more about what city improvements are desired, and less joke tweets (which only seem to be a small handful that are frequently repeated).  Like I said, very minor quibbles. The core structure of the game and the gameplay itself are PERFECT for old SimCity fans. Traffic actually works (if you plan your infrastructure right). The UI is very user friendly. The visuals are beautiful. The 'Sims' themselves actually have real, consistent jobs and homes, rather than going to random jobs and returning to random homes.  I can't even imagine the logistical nightmare it must has been to code all of these algorithms for traffic, sim residency and job placement, combined with education levels, and a whole host of other factors.  But they did it.  Also, of course - NO ONLINE-ONLY REQUIREMENTS, NO DRACONIAN DRM, and ACTUAL LARGE CITY SIZES. Plus so much more.  Fair warning: my city has only reached about 5,500 population, so some of the issues I've described might change as the game progresses. But from what I've read, the game doesn't suddenly collapes into anarchy at higher levels.  Finally verdict - a MUST BUY for oldschool SimCity fans who were heavily disappointed with EA's last abortion of an attempt.

Cities: Skylines is a city building sim in the style of Sim City. For the last years, city building sims have been in a bit of decline. Monte Cristo entered into the market with their Cities series of games, which pushed the genre forwards, allowing bendy roads, non-circular radii for building effects and dynamically zoned areas. They pushed the genre forwards, but being as innovative as they are, they went bankrupt and didn't quite do it right.  Maxis, the undisputed rulers of this genre, came out with the latest SimCity which tried to respond to these developments. The result was a game that was interesting, had potential, but was seriously bugged and couldn't handle city sizes of any decent size. In doing so, Maxis undoubtedly shot themselves in the foot.  Along come Colossal Order, who don't have any experience in the genre, but did make Cities in Motion 1 and 2. Having played the second one, it's obvious that the engine they created for the CiM series is actually pretty damn good, something that could be adapted to make a proper city simulation game. Hence the, I was going to say hype, but it's more expectation. People were saying that, should they do an even passable job of adapting their engine, the game should be really good.  I've been playing it and... I can say it's truly amazing. I've managed to grow a city from nothing to 80,000 inhabitants and the games attention to detail is truly stunning. Where the game excels is the road modelling and transport. Place junctions too close to each other, fail to design a highway interchange correctly and everything comes to a grinding halt. Once that happens, city services, which use the roads, start to clog up and undertakers can't collect corpses, garbage stops being collected. Industry can't deliver, police cars can't get to crime scenes and ambulances can't get to medical emergencies. In short, everything goes very badly to hell.  Zoning is based around the roads. By placing roads, little squares show up next to them, in which it's possible to paint zones in any way you want. So, if you want a mainly residential block with corner shops, that's eminently doable. Or office areas with small commercial units tucked into them so that your office drones can grab their morning coffee, that's doable too.  Electricity is spread naturally from adjacent building to adjacent building, but power lines make a comeback. If a gap between powered areas is too wide, no electricity gets to them. The game cares about things like windspeed too, so placing green turbines is a real art form now, with areas being better or worse for wind. The whole level of detail recalls Sim City 4.  The water system is similarly filled with detail. You have water pumps that pump water from the river and sewage pipes that put waste water back in. Put your sewage pipes upriver of your water pumps and... bad things happen. The game cares about water flow and water direction and even has a water model, so when you build that hydro-electric dam across your river, more bad things can happen. Underground pipes spread water and remove sewage from neighbourhoods, which you have to draw.  Public transport is also fun but, bizarrely for a game that descends from one that was designed exclusively about this, it isn't as satisfying as it could be. The rail system is excellent and ports work amazingly. I created a port-side industrial zone and gave it a rail connection and the industrial zone around it went into a mass fit of productivity and investment, which is the first time in any city building game that's happened. The number of times I've tried to zone proper port districts and failed beggars belief. However, the bus system, although simplified, can be a bit hard to use and place lines, while metro systems remain totally below ground and you can't cross paths by having one line go below another. The platforms on the stations are awkward to place and the system could do with a bit of a tweak, which serves to make an excellent system merely good.  Cities: Skyline also passes one amazingly important test, which is hard to adequately quantify. It's that of building a city based on how you know your local city or town to work and having the game actually pick up on that and work with you. Cities: Skylines passes this test superbly. I could replicate structures and road patterns I actually see and have them work or not work with effects that match what I see in real life. It creates a game with a great feel. For example, the success of my port district then overloaded the local highway interchange. Trying to fix that was an exercise in the harsh realities of traffic planning and exactly what should happen with a port district and trying to fix it an education in building large through-flow traffic junctions, like I see near airports in London.  Having played it for a while, there are a couple of bugbears I'd like to pick up. The park system is one of them. Parks are rectangular, which makes for awkwardness and difficulty placing them. In the Cities franchise, parks could be made to fit left over area, looking fantastic. I wish this could be done here, to fill in bits and bob left over from non-grid road patterns. Also, something to use dead space in the middle of roads would be good. It would be nice to put parks behind buildings, or create communal gardens. The system also made the Cities franchise farming system work a lot better than it does in Skyline. farms could be dynamically assigned over area between mud track roads.  The second bugbear is that there is no tunnelling. In CiM, roads could be elevated or tunnelled with ease. Here, only elevation works, although the elevation hsystem has been overhauled to be more realistic (no, the pylon supporting your highway can't sprout from the middle of a road). Tunnelling would be such a useful addition and would give some more complication to laying water pipes, which at the moment is a bit simplistic. Both of these are the two biggest shatterers of the almost realistic quality of the simulation.  Cities: Skyline is the most innovative game of the city building genre to come along in a very long time. It's attention to detail is refreshing and wonderful. I can't recommend it enough.

Amazing replacement to the Simcity series; graphics are a little more whimsical than what would be considered realistic, but that's totally fine. Regardless of such; there are still plenty of other areas to manage, so it will keep you busy regardless.  Do buy.

Cities Skyline is the modern city building game that individuals like myself have been waiting for since Simcity 4. With the utter disaster that Simcity 2013 was (and let's not forget Simcity Societies, before that), there was a void of proper city building games out there on the market. The only other would have been Cities XXL or whatever rebrand they have done with very little actual change to the original release years ago.  This game, made by Colossal Order, is a game that was made with love and care, and the developers of the game knew what their audience is. Those who play city builder games enjoy their mods, and with the devoted fans that this game has, people have made thousands of new buildings, mods, and vehicles to further enhance what they already made. If you make a good game, and you support your players, then your own fans will make your good game one that will be played for years after you make it, like Simcity 4 was.   Is it a perfect game? No, but what game is? The one thing that Simcity 2013 had that I'd enjoy an introduction to in Cities: Skyline is modular buildings like hospital and universities that allowed you to design sprawling complexes seen at real universities and hospitals. Hopefully in another patch or expansion this comes to us, but this is a small feature that I would enjoy in an otherwise amazing game.

Having played longer I feel like updating my review. The game is really great in principle and I still happily recommend it. The good points are all over the 'net and the core gameplay is very enjoyable. However there are issues that become very evident at higher population levels and other than designing your city entirely to work around the game's design mechanics or using mods, the player isn't given tools to combat these issues. This is very unfortunate as it makes building large, realistic-feeling yet functional cities seemingly impossible without 'gaming' the game. I'll be focusing on the negatives here, hopefully they'll get fixed eventually. Polished large-scale city gameplay combined with the game's ridiculously good modding support would probably make me play this game happily for the next 10 years.  The main problem is how the traffic works. Traffic in the game can be roughly divided into commuters, deliveries, services and industry import/export. The industry, delivery and service traffic function in a fairly intuitive manner and there's nothing specifically wrong with how they operate. However the more general traffic issues outlined below causes huge industry traffic blockages and completely negates services as the service vehicles can never get where they're supposed to, with ultimately citizens moving out because bodies and trash never get collected. Similarly commercial deliveries can take such a long time that businesses start shutting down.  The game is very happy with placing traffic lights but doesn't have green waves. AI drivers don't use multiple lanes efficiently and they don't take current amount of traffic on their route into consideration, thus completely saturating any chokepoints instead of taking alternative routes that are completely open. Buses actually make the situation worse in high-traffic situations because there are no bus lanes, and a bus stopping to pick up passengers entirely blocks the traffic behind it. The game seems to decide the number of buses on a given route very arbitrarily and the buses aren't spaced out temporally so they tend to form massive bus queues that others cannot bypass.  Service and delivery vehicles cause a similar blocking problem because while they're doing their thing they can't be bypassed either, which leads the traffic degrading into stop-start-stop-start pattern on busy roads. Green waves, more control over traffic lights (and smarter automatic placement, as they definitely are useful at times) and bus/service lanes would mitigate these issues greatly.  Commuters barely ever seems to use trains, even though they're potentially the fastest transport for long routes. The number of tourists coming in, either by train, car or boat, is so minimal there isn't any point in building transport for them. The train AI also occasionally seems to deadlock, possibly because of the large number of trains the system spawns. In-city cargo trains from industrial areas getting sent to depots in areas that are completely gridlocked also just makes the traffic worse, even though generally the cargo train depots are a great way of controlling where the industrial goods traffic flows. The game could monitor how efficiently goods are being distributed all the way to their destinations from any given depot at a given time and prefer better working depots, thus giving depots in oversaturated areas time to breathe.  The player can't really find out what the root causes of their traffic issues are at any given time, which compounds all the specific issues with how traffic works. The tools and data just aren't there, or they're really well hidden. Spying on random cars isn't the solution, neither is trying a bunch of random changes to the road network. Giving the player tools to see the overall traffic flows, instead of just 'high traffic here', would allow for actually fixing the problematic areas' core issues, instead of just trying a bunch of random stop-gap measures.  Another valuable aid would be a mechanism that'd allow the player to see how large percentage of people in a given area are using public transport and what their main reasons are for not using it. Currently if one transport route has 20% efficiency and another one 180%, the player can't really find out where the difference comes from. In a similar vein, it'd be really useful to be able to see what the reasons were for any given commuter for choosing the mode of transport they're in. These tools would go a long way to developing actually useful public transport routes.  As for non-traffic issues, unique buildings are almost useless because most of them seem to be worse at improving the environment than plazas, parks etc that are multiple times cheaper and smaller. Since they don't even seem to attract more tourists to your city there's no point in building them. Monuments feel like cheating, for example once you've gotten to a point where you have a well working education system in your city, you're given a building that completely makes all that work redundant. The other monuments are the same, and I never place them in my cities. I don't have all of them unlocked though because of the unlock requirements that require you to actively play the game badly.  The land value system doesn't really make sense because if there are scenic or environmental factors in the calculation, they're unnoticeable. For example green zones, low density high class residential areas or any non-polluted waterfront areas are pointless. Instead you just end up spamming the most effective recreational object everywhere where land value is low. The decoration system is, perhaps, along with the unique buildings and monuments, the game's most lacking aspec. It could do with a complete rehaul, perhaps replacing decorative buildings with recreational zoning that'd level up like RCI zones do and (if in good condition) improve the land value around it.  Wow, that was a long review. I guess it's because I really love the game despite its faults, and as patches and expansions come along I hope I can just erase the entire review paragraph by paragraph.

Cities: Skylines is the game Sim City 5 should have been if it hadnt been cocked up so royally by EA/Maxis from day one.   Now in the interest of full disclosure - I never played Sim City 5. I hate games that force me to be online all the time. I also hate EA being too pigheaded to release games on Steam. However I did follow the gaming disaster that is Sim City 5 in all the news articles and I did belly laugh hard when EA/Maxis's chickens came home to roost like I predicted they would.  Anyway back to C:S - What do I love about it? What do I hate? (short answer: there's nothing really to hate about it, but there is plenty to love).  Pros: + Easy to learn + Cities look great and feel teeming with life + You can rename anything and there doesn't appear to be a character limit + Roads and districts are fun to place + Massive cities!  Cons: - A little too easy (I'm on my first city and it's been no challenge building a fully renewable powered city right from the go) - AA jaggies a bit of a distraction - The max size of zones from road needs to be bigger IMO (the gaps between streets are too small) - Buildings are a bit generic, but DLC and mods are on the way for this - Dams are broken (I've got 2 dams blocking off a river that branches and they're both producing 0 MW yet the arrows show water flowing into one of those dams)  Overall this is a damn (pun intended!) good city builder and anyone who says otherwise needs a frontal lobotomy.

What a great game. I loved the old original Sim City back in the day, but as that franchise wore on it just got worse and worse. More recently I spent a lot of time playing Cities XL, but although it had some great aspects it was a bug-fest and had some serious gameply issues.  This game is, however, one of the best city management games I've played. What makes it such a joy is how intuitive it is, and how well the AI carries out complex placement of objects in a sensible way.  The only thing I feel it misses is more extensive industrial choices - farms and mining, for example, would add a lot of interest and complexity to the economy. This is the one thing Cities XL did well, and it would make this game darn near prefect.  9/10

Preliminary review - All the things you wanted Simcity to be at half the price. Excellent customizability of roadways. Mod support is amazing.  Minor quibbles:  Traffic problems can cause traffic to use only one lane of highways which can create impassible gridlock. I would love to see vehicles use alternate routes if the shortest one has heavy traffic.  The game provides little guidance on what you're doing wrong. We could use more alerts that our utilities are nearing capacity or suggestions on how to alleviate traffic, or design efficient mass transit.  The game is extremely forgiving and encourages iterating. Move special buildings a big help. Bulldoze large neighbourhoods to build that highway. Highway roundabout? Sure thing!  All around amazing, and am excited to see what tweaking is coming.

If you liked Simcity, you will really enjoy yourself with this game. I was not disappointed in where my $30 went this weekend. I did however, run into some stipulations...FYI: Spoiler alerts... 4 major issues come to mind. Read on if you wish, but overall I DO recommend this game for you urban planners out there.  Issue 1. City Stagnation: You can have a perfectly well-ordered city, with all the amenities needed for a perfect life, but if your city does not grow or change zoning placement... It dies. Meaning, if you do not continuously attend your RCI, and try to let your well-optimized city run for a decade or two, people simply leave and it causes a cascade of issues. So either you grow the town, or re-arrange it every few years. Otherwise, it seems like the citizens get bored and move on, or just die and forget to reproduce.  Issue 2. Total anticlimax with the Space Elevator. Seriously. One would assume it goes up and up and up, right? It does not. It is merely a high-tech building that attracts tourists. Don't worry I will get over it, but it is nothing that I imagined a space elevator to look like. Looks more like a Starcraft Terran building, with rotating radar dishes and all, minus the SCVs.  Issue 3. Ridiculous requirements for some locked buildings. Like the Observatory... This completely bothered me so I am going to get harsh here. You literally have to have 1000 abandoned buildings in order to unlock an observatory. I am pretty sure a lot of ancient civilizations unlocked their Observatories simply by looking up, and deciding 'Hey, this is a nice spot.' Somehow, in 'today's world', if you wish to unlock the secret of the heavens, one must first locate a once-occupied urban district, now entirely abandoned, rather than a nice open, high-elevated desert. Makes sense to me!  Issue 4. No Civic Buildings? Yes I know there are fire departments and police departments... But no Town Hall. I really am wondering who runs my city every time I play. I figure it's either the commercial or the office zone people. Or gawd. *Shrug*  Other than that. Great game. Very addictive. Sucked me in and did not let go for the entire weekend. Had a blast. I am sure mods and updates will polish it off. If Simcity 2013 (Other than the tiny city size and no underground, I liked that game) were mixed with this game (Mega Towers and what-not), I would have my mind blown and never be able to play another city-builder again. Paradox games rock, and this hit my top 10. I could discuss the Pros but I think everyone else has covered that. Too many to list.

I am pretty new to the city building genre. The genre has always appealed to me but I never knew which one to choose. I skipped out on SimCity for obvious reasons, then was eventually led to Cities: Skylines. I kept an eye on it as it became what it is today and I purchased it almost knowing I would love it. And I do.  The game was easy for me to learn to play and very addictive once I got into it. The modding community is very active as well as the community in general. There are already tons of extra content available via workshop and almost anything I could think of as a feature that was missing has already been modded into the game.  Gameplay is what I guess you should expect from a city builder. You start off with the basics and work your way up. Just when you think your city is already pretty big, you figure out how to buy more squares of land... Up to 24 more squares. I haven't made it this far yet, but you can definitely make some MASSIVE cities in this game.  Colossal Order has made something special here for sure.

This, is the next generation City building. I've seen Sim City a little bit, and this (Cities: Skylines) looks so much better. People say that this is so much better than Sim City. Now to my opinion. This is a really good game. I love building games, and this is even better than most other building games. Especialy the modding support. The workshop is filled with useful mods and assets. Having a hard time building a highway intersection or just trying to get a good shape on a roundabout? The Workshop is there, filled with tons of intersections you can choose from. Sick of seeing the same Police Cars/Firetrucks all the time. Search for new models on the Workshop, same with houses. In Cities: Skylines, unlike other games, every citizen is simulated, going to work, going to the store, health, happiness, feelings, thoughts. The game also features its own Twitter, which can give you useful data of what the people need. This is one of the best City building games ever. I really recommend this game. I give this game the score of 11/10.

I also wasn't sure that this game would run well on my nearly 4-year old Mac, but with a few reduced graphics settings it is runnning fine! Would definitely recommend this!

I'll be honest, I'm not big on city simulation games. I've tried older versions of SimCity (and not the infamous 2013 one) and I just could not get into it. This, however, I can get sucked into for hours on end. There's just something so... magical about watching your city grow from a tiny town into a huge metropolis. Watching people move in, go about their daily lives. It's just so magical and I love it. Admittedly, I'm not the best city planner out there, but watching my cities grow makes me want to try harder, as if I'm actually the mayor of the city and those models representing people are my constituents. I want to keep them happy, even though I know that in reality they're just virtual.  The mechanics are very in-depth. Don't educate your people well enough and businesses that need educated workers will shut down, but if you require everyone to get an education your businesses might not have enough workers to operate and shut down. Will you build a residential zone in this area you just built, or will you build industry there? What about power; will you have enough? Should you use coal power or wind power? I love things like this, they really make me think about what to do before I act and in the end it's very rewarding.  Oh yeah, you can district different parts of your city, and enforce different policies per district. As in, you want your industry to recycle as well as having smoke detectors, while another part of town just enforces smoke detectors and somewhere you don't want people to have pets (such as an apartment complex), you can ban pets, all without any policies overlapping one another. How cool is that?  However, it's not without its faults. Police are overpowered while the fire department is underpowered, traffic management in the base game is poor and criminal justice (again, in the base game) is very barebones. Also, you don't unlock some very environment-protecting assets until your city reaches a population of 16000; in my opinion, some of them, such as waste treatment plants, should be unlocked sooner. Chirper, the in-game version of Twitter, is also a mixed bag; it tends to give you useful information about how your citizens feel, but they also tend to overuse #hashtags and it gets really annoying to find out that your #cat was saved by a #smokedetector for the 15 billionth time. It's also full of jokes and pop culture references. Take that last one as you will.  So, overall, do I recommend Cities: Skylines? YES! Especially if you're big on simulation games. If not, it's still worth checking out; you might be pleasantly surprised, as was I.

The perfect city builder. If you like Sim City, you will adore this game. If you don't like Sim City, there's a pretty good chance you will still like this. Most of the ideas of the Sim City (such as zones) are in this game, and function similarly.   Definetly one of the best games I've gotten on steam, this is a must-have game if you have a steam account. I give 10/10.   Now I will be the typical Steam reviewer and have fun.  You start off as a very small town with a main road. Everyone that moves into your town is essentially stupid, as adults haven't even attended elementary school. So some of your beginning Industrial places will be so desperate for workers they pay them so much they can buy uneducated oafs sports cars and nice upper middle class suburban homes on the edge of the ocean. Ah, I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game.

A very fun and addictive, if sometimes frustrating city builder.   Pros: -extensive modding community -very easy to get into for people new to the genre -wide variety of maps, and the size is very large (not like Sim City where the map is ridiculously tiny) -graphics look great, especially with the tilt-lens effect -many different ways to build your city -interface is very user-friendly and easy to understand  Cons:  -bus line system is a bit confusing, game doesn't really explain well how it works -some issues with optimization, gets frame skips and crashes a lot even on my high end PC -the game doesn't have as large of a variety of buildings as it seems like it should -it can be difficult at times to tell why your city's happiness level is decreasing  Despite the issues it has, Cities Skylines is excellent. This is one of those games that will keep you up late at night going 'Okay, I'll just put a few more buildings here, and then I'll stop...' and just when you think you're done, you'll want to come back and play more. Overall 9/10.

This is the first review of a game that I have ever given, so please bear with me:   This is the game, that despite me getting older, I have been going to for it's shear ability ot amaze me. I am purchasing and downloading the expansion DLC as we speak.   <b>The good:</b>   This is a classic city builder that follows and expands upon a tried an true system first started way back when with simcity. When I see a quintessential city builder, I think it should follow that sme basic pattern of feeling like god. You are placed in this third person role of creating something bigger than yourself and hoping that you can make the best, most beautiful city you've ever seen. To guide or crush your subjects as you see fit. Does Skylines achieve this feeling? Yes, yes and more yes. This game is classic iteration on an amazing concept introduced long ago. Do you feel like god? Hell yes. Can you build something great? Yes! Not just great but unique and beautiful that's all your own. Can you create some dystopian hell hole? Yes! Pollution and crime can run amok as you scour your terrain looking for a good place to build industry and power plants to choke your people who have no education or even way to dispose of the many bodies you are creating.   This game is the city builder which future builders should be compared against. This is the new 'gold standard.'   Purchase this game because I am sure you will have it in your back pocket for rainy days years to come. Enjoy it. Get lost in the scenic vistas. Get lost in the zen enjoyment of creation.   <b>The cons:</b>  When I attempted to use the terrain builder to make a map it felt very cumbersome and was not enjoyable and easy to use as it could be. I did't find it enjoyable at all to create maps, it felt like work. I am sure I will come back to it but I think it should be easier to use.   <b>Rating:</b>  Rating 10/10 because I didn't even expect to be able to make maps in game, despite the cumbersome interface it was an unexpected surprise to have this ability in the first place.  As for the game I purchased: the city builder. It's perfect. Keep making great things devs, and know that you have really hit the nail on the head.

This is the new king of city builders. After the demise of Sim City, the throne was left vacant, but fortunately not for long! I cannot recommend this game highly enough for those of you who like me have been waiting for a good city builder game. The graphics are awesome, the citizens actually do have homes and jobs and little virtual lives that you can view. The entire game has a high level of polish and the UI is very well done.  The game isn't hard - you don't have to worry about losing. Instead it focuses on setting your own goals and giving you a giant sandbox in which to accomplish them. The scale of the cities you can build is pretty huge (and there are mods to make it even huger). Your biggest problem is traffic, adding a pseudo puzzle quality to the game. I'm constantly on the lookout for ways to make my cities transportation network more efficient so I can wedge in a few more people. Fortunately, the toolset for managing traffic is very deep. You can just slap down roads and let the citizens fend for themselves, or you can dive in and spend days tweaking intersections, crosswalks, one-/two-way streets, street light positions, etc.  I love this game, and I can recommend it with no reservations.

Cities: Skylines is a more complex, if not fun and laid back look on The Sims and SimCity. From the very start of the game, I had no idea wtf I was doing....the tutorials served little to no help about more advanced things that needed to be known in order for the city to thrive, and not reach an economic depression.  However, after playing it for an hour, I knew exactly what I needed to do with everything...and its one of those games where if you have trouble in the beginning figuring out wtf to do, you learn as you go. Then, once you understand the basics and the intermediate things, you feel powerful enough to make your starting town into a metropolis of your dreams.  Cities: Skylines is without doubt one of the more unique takes on the City Simulator/Creator/Tycoon genre, and is well worth the buy if you're up to an hour of frustrating pooper-dupes, to the rest being smooth sailing down the canal of toliet.  Yeh, I know what I said, deal with it xD.  I give this game a solid 8.5/10  I'd give it a 9/10, but there is very VERY few hints given when you need them most, esp as a newer player (a few months back). Maybe add in a tutorial save and make new players play this, and let them choose to skip to a fresh save. Tutorial world should explain all the nooks and crannies, instead of throwing the person into a new save and have them learn as they go. Either method works, but the a true tutorial would have saved me hours of frustration.  I digress: still a fun-♥♥♥ game! :D

Simcity sits on the highest pedestal in Simulationland. 'Sim' is in the title. Admit it, we all spent weeks in the computer den building our perfect metropolis in Simcity 4 (which is still king; it's not even dead yet). And, we were all lead astray and massacred by the 2013 Simcity, which, honestly, lowered said pedestal the franchise had sat on for years.  In the ensuing darkness following the announcement of that Simcity including offline play (at that point, everyone was dead), there was a savior. A knight in well-used but not dull armor, who spoke slightly broken English and promised that city simulators would have their own Backstreet Boys-style comeback.  Cities: Skylines delivers.  The real 3D city building experience we thought Maxis would provide us with ages ago was instead supplied by a team of less than a dozen Scandiavians. An all-encompassing experience of zoning and sewage, for less than average price. On top of being easy to look at and hard to put down, there's a surprisingly large modding community for even more fun.  Is it the 3D equivalent of Simcity 4? No. But Cities: Skylines is chipping away at that pedestal with an axe, and there'll come a tipping point.

I've spent over 70 hours in this game (Steam lies for some reason) the last week or two, and I really love this game. That's a lot of entertainment and well worth the money.  (There's a TL;DR of sorts at the bottom)  It deliciously picks up the city simulation genre and is almost all I wanted a modern Sim City to be. Almost. There are some things that slowly started to... nag. Some things feel like they're lacking, like events. Any events. Other than buildings being abandoned or burning down.  Say, for example, some political alignments in your Cims. Strikes if you don't handle industry well for the workers, or business moving elsewhere if the industry executives feel disappointed with you. Maybe even riots, with things going South, if you don't handle the strikes. More... citizen dynamics. You still have happiness but over time it kind of feels mostly like it's enough to place a couple of parks and service buildings nearby an area and everyone's happy. Not really a challenge.  Traffic is a challenge, and I love it. But the 'only' real problem with traffic is congestion (and route length I guess). If people or delivery trucks won't reach their destinations fast enough, it can hurt the economy quite a bit. However, there are no such things as accidents, which would've been kind of cool to deal with somehow. Not only to plan roads that allow for good flow, but that keeps the risk of accidents low.  I won't really mention the bugs too much. There are bugs, like dead bodies not being picked up sometimes even though the cemetary is across the street, but it's merely a small nuisance and not overly game-breaking. Then there's the kind of dull limitation when building things on slopes. It feels like it says 'Slope too steep' a little too often, and I would love to be able to build more wavy towns.  I'm no expert by any means but I don't aspire to be one either. I play this kind of game to be immersed in a believable city simulation where I actually feel I care for the people in the town. I don't like it when I start seeing only numbers and stats, which it feels like I've drifted towards doing lately. I'll keep playing it because I still enjoy it, and maybe I'll understand things about it that makes me appreciate it even more.  Personally, I would love more varied and relevant Chirper (the in-game virtual twitter thing) messages, or a news paper like in Sim City 2000, or maybe gifts and favors from happy citizens, or random festivals. Business proposals from other cities or whatever. Events to shake things up, where you either try to deal with what's suddenly happening or can make interesting choices. 'Hey, NASA wants to build a launch base. It'll take a lot of room, but you'll get tons of money!' More control of the range and funding of separate service buildings.  The bottom line for me I think is that I would love more life. Sure, there's visually tons of life in the city. Thousands of people and cars and bikes and dogs. They're probably very important and 'real' for the simulation, too. But there's something lacking in the 'personal' connection between me and them. The Chirper gets way too repetitive to work as such a connection for longer than an hour or two, in my opinion. I want to see them angry, sad and happy. Stressed and relaxed... etc.  Also, more management. More control, especially over city services. Let me pick a priority area for trash collection, for example, or maybe order a certain police station to focus patrols on a certain area, or tell a hospital to focus on an area. Maybe let me lower or increase funding to a specific service building (now there's only an ON and OFF for a building).  Of course, there are mods for the game that adds complexity, which is really great and I respect the game developers for adding that ability (managing mods is a breeze) and the modding community for producing such advanced stuff. Hoping that we'll see the API getting broader and that we get more DLC that officially flesh out more parts of the game. After Dark was a nice little bit of candy, but it still feels like there's a lot that can be added to really make the package feel complete.  An attempt at a TL;DR... It's a great game. Looks great, sounds great, plays great. Even runs pretty great on Linux (Mint). Great modding support, and great tools for making your own assets and even custom buildings from within the game. You'll spend a lot of hours of lovingly growing and taking care of your city, and there's plenty of visual variation. Traffic planning is a really fun challenge. I'm hoping that more depth and control is added to city services, and that the citizens can be made to feel more real and 'human' and less like stats. I'd like interesting and relevant events to happen. A pinch of politics would be nice.

This is the game that Simcity 2014 should have been but wasn't, which is incredible, because it was made with 10% of the staff at Maxis and (I'm guessing) a fraction of the budget.  Pros: - Great simulation of agents. Unlike Simcity, Cities: Skylines tracks where your citizens live and work, as well as their level of education, whether or not they own a car, and their age. If you want to actually follow people around on their day to day lives, this game makes that possible. - Very flexible road and highway tools. - Easy modding integration with Steam means that there is a ton of user made content to play with. - Map and asset editor in game. - Massive maps that can be modded to be even larger if you'd like. - User friendly interface that makes this game great for people new to the genre. - An upbeat soundtrack. - Well optimized. Loads quickly and runs smoothly. - $30 on release is a very fair price for what you get.  Cons: - No day / night cycle, weather, or seasons. - Limited structure assets. Lots of repeated buildings around cities. - Complicated traffic structures are tough to pull off in game (though can be made, slowly, in the asset editor). - Almost every aspect of the game (even data menus) has to be unlocked by population. This can be disabled with a built in mod, but some buildings and features feel like they should be unlocked. - Unique buildings are locked out with a mini achievement-like system that feels arbitarily. This can also be disabled with a built in mod, but it seems like they should instead have a different method of unlocking. - The game's 'chirps' are a mix between helpful messages and spam.  All in all, the pros outweight the cons tremendously, and if you like city building games, then you shouldn't miss this one for any reason.

Either way, tons of fun, totally 10/10 in my book.

Very enjoyable game to play. I like to sit back with some relaxing music of my own and just play this game for a few hours. I have never played a Sims game so I can't compare Cities to that series. However, I did grow up playing the Roller Coaster Tycoon series and to me this game is very reminiscent of that.  The steam workshop in this game really helps with the longevity of the game. It keeps things fresh and really allows you to personalize your city.  The only issues that I have ever had are:   1. The game can be confusing to new players, the lack of instruction is almost as if CO expects you to have played the first Cities game.  However, guides can very easily be found on Youtube as well as right here on Steam.  2. The extremely long load times when your city starts to get up in the 80,000+ range in terms of population.  However, it's expected since the city at that point is fairly large, and whatever you have placed in the world from the workshop only makes the load times longer.   3. Corrupt maps when you delete some buildings/monuments from your world that you have downloaded from the workshop.  This is less of a problem for me now, when the game first came out it was a big issue and I have recently found myself being able to go back to my corrupt maps and begin rebuilding! Huge ++  4. The frame drop in larger cities is almost unbearable.  Again, this is expected since it can be very crowded in some places. It's a personal issue for me since I have a habit of building metropoleis full of workshop skyscrapers. I'm sure the problem would be at least a little less noticeable in cities that are more spread out.  All in all, I think this game is well worth whatever price you happen to find it at. I haven't purchased the After Dark DLC yet, but I do plan to do so now that I am getting back into this game with my old cities functioning properly again!

Solid simulation game overall, highly enjoyable alternative to Sim City-esque options.   The game falls short in some areas, mainly the inclusion of various modern technologies (such as water treatment and purification, desalination, so on). The most bothersome quality about this game is the numerous visual layers (water, electric, pollution, traffic, etc.), which though wonderful in and of themselves, are pretty much the only way you can navigate the game at night. The map gets incredibly dark, and does nothing to assist you with building or modifying your city until sunrise, forcing you to awkwardly hop through view layers to actually see what you're doing, since these effectively disable night until escaped out of.  Edit: In addition, the longer one goes in playing this game, the more frustrating one tends to find some of the more obvious limitations. One is terraforming. Super obvious, and no good reason why it isn't build into the game. Relying on community mods is an option, but points towards laziness from the developers.

So many options...) but that's just me--I think that's a selling point for most people. I like that it has built-in goals and unlockables, and it provides a sense of progression and accomplishment I think many other building games lack. The community is great, lots of cool downloadable extras. No bugs, no issues.   Better than Sim City by far, way more intuitive and interesting. If you're torn between the two, go with this one.

This game is one of the best city builders out there. I havent put too much time in the game. But I have a 20,000 population city and is making a ton of money. Here are a few tips to help get you started:  1. Make use of all of the land possible. This means you can zone all of the land inside of the square or rectange of road. Maintaining roads cost a lot. This made me restart my city a few times.  2. Raise your tax to 11%. I know it sounds like a lot lol but this is the highest you can go without the cims complaining.  3. Lower your budget a bit. You can lower every budget panel to 75% exept power and electricity. You can keep that at 100%.  4. Do not use districts untill a much higher level or not use them at all. Using districts cost a ton of money so if you ask me, dont use them.  5. Make a lot of garbage dumps. But do not place them next to residential areas. Make them somewhat spread around your city.  Hope this guide helped you start your first city! This game is really fun so I want to make sure you get the most out of this game!!

I never thought that you could sit in front of game for hours trying to tweak traffic and enjoy the expierience. The game itself is in its basics quite typical for a City Management Game, you build roads, provide water and electricity and define zones where your sims will build up houses, industie and commerce. Contrary to most other games though, they actually go as far as to simulate every single sim living in your city. That means that Mr. Simons, working at the Pawn Shop downtown, will actually get up in the morning and try to get to work. So depending on your cities public transport he will either use the bus , tram, underground or the car. Of course he will then in the evening return home, go shopping or anything else he might think of. As the city grows it will become more and more challenging to provide a working traffic management.  Manageing traffic however is just one of the many cogs that the player will need to manipulate in order to keep his or her city healthy. Education, Trash, Health and Safety are also things to consider. You also have a plentitude of edicts you can give out to change things in your city.   I really liked the micromanagement part and spent hours and hours working on my city. I think i trashed the first four cities because I learned later that I could have done several things a lot smoother and deceided to start again. This didnt really lessen the fun of the game though. I strongly recommend this game for people who want to take their time playing a game. If you look for a quick session once in a while you might not be happy with City Skylines because it always takes a lot of time to get back into the flow when not remembering what in your city was to be done next.   There are loads of interessting Addons in the Workshop, a few nice maps and many many custom buildings.

==Personal Thoughts== For me (and evidently for many others), Cities: Skylines fills in the hole that was left behind when SimCity flopped, and does so remarkably well. This is a good game. It's also not that expensive, so if you're looking for a modern city simulator, buy it.  ==The Good== + People used to other city builder games will adapt to this one very quickly. + Cloud syncing! I have my SimCity 4 data synced to my Dropbox. It's nice to have this kind of feature baked into the game. + Far better than SimCity at handling elevated/underground transportation, and offers curved roads on top of that. + Per-district policies. + Lots of mods and other third-party content. + User-friendly interface. + It runs on Linux and Mac.  ==The Bad== + Doesn't really have a tutorial built in, so new players are immediately thrown into the deep end. + Game engine is fairly demanding. The GPU isn't too important; my desktop's 750 Ti is more than enough, and if I run it on near-minimum settings, I can even get it to run on my laptop's HD Graphics 3000. However, running large cities at speed requires a LOT of CPU power, and my aging computers can't keep up. Cities: Skylines is designed to try and avoid FPS drops, so the actual gameplay remains smooth, but once the city reaches a substantial size, the flow of time slows down quite badly. I imagine that a modern Core i5 would handle it fine.  ==Other Thoughts== + More so than with SimCity 4, and especially more so than with older SimCity installments (e.g. 3000 and 2000), Cities: Skylines requires that you be somewhat clever with your city layout. Commercial zones need very reliable connections to industrial zones, or they won't have any goods to sell and will close. Industrial zones need good outside connections so they can import the raw materials they need to create goods. Fossil fuel power plants will shut down if they can't get the resources they need, so it's more optimal to place them near structures such as highways and rails. You'll ESPECIALLY have to pay attention to your transportation grid, as Cities: Skylines is much fussier about transportation than SimCity. Put some thought into your roads before building then, or you'll end up desperately and hilariously hacking more and more stuff into the grid in vain hopes that eventually, SOMETHING will improve. Fused grid layouts and roundabouts generally produce good results.  ==Some differences from SimCity== + City boundaries can be expanded. + Unlike in SimCity 4, and as with earlier SimCity titles, you control only a single city, not a whole region. + Sewage processing is a requirement and not having it will cause sewage to back up into people's houses. For obvious reasons, sewage drains should be located downstream from pumping stations. + Some means of processing dead people is required (e.g. cemetaries or crematoriums). + No medium-density zones. + Mass transit lines must be manually drawn; in SimCity, they are automatically calculated. + Per-district policies and ordinances. + More control over industrial zones (e.g. you can specify oil industry, forestry, etc.) + No elevated subways or monorails. However, elevated train tracks are present as mentioned in the pros, so that offsets the loss. + Utilities don't break down after a preset amount of time. + No natural gas power plants. + Offshore wind turbines are a thing. + Hydroelectric dams exist and will cause flooding if built. + The fusion power plant, if you unlock it, is enough to singlehandedly power the entire city at maximum size. This isn't different from SimCity 4, but it's definitely different from SimCity 3000. + Highways are one-directional, so you have to lay them in both directions. + Has four- and six-lane roads as opposed to SimCity's avenues. One wonders why you'd ever use four-lane roads, and the answer is that they produce less noise from traffic. + No recycling centers. Recycling is instead handled as a policy. + Neighbor deals are nonexistent, but transportation in and out of the city is still relevant and must be handled adequately.

Having problems with traffic? Here's some tips to avoid conjestion. - Roundabouts are your friend. - Avoid creating traffic lights.  - Use one-way streets as much as possible. - Don't put intersections too close to each other. - Have multiple routes to one area. - Highways help move traffic faster. - Have a balance of large roads (eight lane highways) and small roads (2 lane roads).

I have about 6 years experience with city building games. It started with SimCity 4, then SimCity Societies (Yuck), SimCity 2013 (Huge downgrade from SC4), and then finally Cities Skylines. In my opinion SimCity 4 and Cities Skylines are tied as the best city building games at this point. With the modding community of both games, Cities Skylines has likely overtaken Sim city 4 with all the support it has, the DLC (Which isn't too expensive), and the assets/mods. Highly recommend this game to anyone, regardless of their preferred genre.

Great game, well implemented, no issues for me at all on Win 7 64 bit, 20GB ram, and Nvidia 750i card.  I dont write many reviews but this product deserves it, so here goes.  My only criticisms, might be:    documentation regarding placement of intersections, train stations etc, how to rotate them, but the answers are all available. Select item, right click and drag to rotate, easy to do once you know.    the inability to undo.......but at least you get a refund for destruction.     difficulty in making bus routes go where you want them. My solution make more stops to limit possible paths.    workshop add-on to show angles of curves and snap points great for precise control of road curves, and shapes, should be part of the game.  The workshop and editor make a good product, great!  Short of adding different visuals, I cant think of anything significant to make this a better product.  Suggestions:    Possibly the ability to control timing of traffic lights, users could create a traffic light object and save the timing.    Parking lots, or control of parking on the side of road, effectively making it wider for heavy traffic.    Use of GPS to determine the fastest route based on traffic flow, and policies.    Creation of traffic monitoring object for a limited area to work with GPS.    Accidents    Mountainous terrain limiting traffic, resources and development ruining enviroment and tourism.    Cities split by national boundaries (build a wall) and nations with different labour, infrastructure and tax issues.  Very well done, as far as city builders go 9.6 out of 10! ;-)

Some bad stuff:    Making certain desired roads, crossroads and high speed connections - utterly frustrating, if not impossible.    Trying to find even medium level useful statistics that would allow making correct choices for adjusting certain services - utterly impossible.    Aligning anything underground correctly - same as making the crossroads - utterly frustating.    Correctly or even somewhat realistically working water physics - not in this game.    Arranging public transportation to work efficiently - impossible.    Trying to get traffic to use lanes even half smartly - apparently needs mods.    Trying to create a dam to the desired height - either impossible or nearly impossible, or about hour of trial and error if lucky with the nearby map. All above and even more some negatives in effect,  the good stuff outweights the bad stuff many times over . TL;DR: I would recommend it, though it is not as good as Sim City 4.  Long version:  Cities: Skylines was the answer of a joke called Sim City (2013), which maybe has been the worst city-building-game in history. C:S took a loot of things from SC13 and made it better. You still have zoning and you start in a small area, but since you start your game by 0 with only a few dollarinos, it's part of your own development as a mayor to expand your borders, claim new building spaces and expand your city or instead build several small villages. You can look up on Youtube for really good cities which have been created with this game; and if you take your time to build your city slowly, you can experience a nice time while watching your city growing by getting bigger and becoming more educated and richer.   But there are still some flaws within the game which really made me upset.  1) All your buildings need a street connection. You cannot place a park in the middle of a block, no, they NEED a connection. This results, if you have big blocks with a non-building-space in the middle, in a green void filled by a few trees and pedestrian streets.  2) the good thing is: You have several industrial zones: farming, metal works, forest industry and the common industry. The bad thing is: You have to unlock everything except the common industry. So when you finally can place farms (very small ones I want to add) you already have several districts with high polluting industry buildings. Remember in SC4, when you could build small farm villages from the start on, with a farmer's market and big ♥♥♥ field? Not gonna happen in C:S.  3) You even have to unlock streets. This isn's a bad thing. The bad thing is, that in the beginning you have to high way lanes ending in your territory, marking the outside connection for your city. The very first street you have to build must connect with this street-limbs, or else nobody will be able to move to your town. You are forced to connect 2-lane-road to each of the endings (each highway lane is a one direction road, why the ♥♥♥♥ ever, I'm not familiar with the highway design in the US). This looks ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as ♥♥♥♥, since every two-lane-road has also a sidewalk, even if it's in the middle of nowhere. Also the transition from highway to normal street looks not good. 4) The AI is ♥♥♥♥ing awful. Imagine this: You have a three lane highway, every lane leads into the same direction. Somewhere in the distance there is a freeway exit to your industrial district. And a few hundred meters after that, there is another exit for your city. Now every. ♥♥♥♥ing. vehicle is taking the right lane, no matter if the other lanes are completly unused. There will be a huge traffic jam, because a lot of vehicles try to take the first exist to a normal street, where also many cars are waiting in front of a traffic light [red]. The ones who want to drive to your city just stay in the traffic jam until they can move on, still on the right lane. It's ridiculous it can really upset you, trust me, 'cause the traffic statistics tell you that there is a huge traffic overload and you can't do ♥♥♥♥ to prevent it.  5) flat ♥♥♥ maps. Remember Sim City, when you can start next to a big ♥♥♥ mountain? Well, the maps of C:S are all as flat as Paris Hilton and look as empty as her eyes.   Of course there are mods out there. And there are many awesome mods which provides you more depth in your statistics and stuff. Also there is a huge, HUGE amount of additional buildings for every zone you can place on your map. Mods can fix everything of the said problems, except the driving AI. But if you use mods, you can't get your achievements. I guess this game is like Skyrim. It becomes really good if you mod the ♥♥♥♥ out of it. I'm one of the few players who like vanilla games aswell and finish everything in vanilla before modding it. And the vanilla game itself is pretty weak. Remember in Sim City 4, when the first skyscraper plopped up? It was like defeating Smough and Ornstein solo for the first time. When the first skyscrapers appeared in C:S, I didn't feel anything. I guess I'm dead from the inside. Or maybe this game doesn't have as much heart and soul in it as I expected it to have. Or maybe both.   But: It still is the best modern city-building-game out there. If you like to creat small comfy villages: This game is not designed to provide you this stuff, it's build to create big cities. It still cannot beat Sim City 4. The soundtrack is also not as good. Nothing can beat the SC4-Soundtrack.  EDIT: The game makes much more fun with the day-and-night-cycle.

It is a solid city simulator, and with Natural Disasters it looks like it will truly be Sim City 4's spiritual sucessor.   However the traffic AI does still have issues, at the very least on left-hand drive roads, where it tends to get in lane well before the junction and use the left most lane solely, which is what the Highway Code might say is best practice, but is not particularly human-like and leads to some issues.   Also I wish there were all the variants of the roads for trams, buses and bikes (i.e. two-lane with tress and a bike lane).  It is also starting to get a little bloated by Paradoxes strategy allowing you to mod it heavily and then throwing a handful new features in extra dlc.  But, all in all, it is still a very good game.

Solid, but basic gameplay out of the box. Incredible size and scope. Impressive and extensive modding support. Game rewards you for planning ahead and making clever mass transit choices. Disappointing graphics, unless you're able to run it at 4k resolution. Needs a lot of mods, and a potent gaming PC to get the most out of it. A great game, although for me feels a little sterile at times.  Pros:-  *Vanilla version provides a solid, albeit basic city building experience, with a minimum of 36 sq. km of space to build on without mods. As expansions were released game shipped with day/night cycle, and weather as part of the game. *Scope of maps, and buildable area up to 324 sq. km with mods. *Very strong modding community. *The biggest strength of this game is in the transportation model. While basic in vanilla, without mods, does reward you for good planning and execution. *By far the best city builder out at the moment, with the devs regularly updating and making improvements.  Cons:-  *You need a lot of mods to get the most out of this game - the basic game experience is good, but with mods it makes it a whole lot better/flexible. *While some will disagree, you do need a pretty potent gaming rig to run this well. But to be fair, anything over 20fps while fully zoomed in is more than playable. *At 1080p, for me the graphics are disappointing, even at max detail. Big issue is quality of AA in game engine. But, in defense of the devs, the scope of this game goes a long way to make up for it. *Game can feel a little sterile at times. At the risk of being really unfair, sometimes this game doesn't feel as fun as SimCity 2013 did for me (flaws of that game and all).

Until this title came up in the sale I hadn't really paid much attention to it as I have been a long term fan of the grand-daddy of the genre - Sim City - right from its early days on my old trusty Commodore Amiga. The last decade or so have been spent living in Sim City 4 which with countless mods has become the game I'd always wanted - albeit now a little dated. So when the sale price for Skylines grabbed my attention the first thing I went off and searched about t'interweb was 'Sim City 4 vs Cities: Skylines'. The results you will find are pretty much unanimously that it is the natural successor starting where SC4 is now with all its mod base... so I bit the bullet - and I am VERY pleased I did. Move over SC4 - your crown has well and truely been usurped. Skylines is FANTASTIC. It provides the full 3D experience of your city in stunning quality and variety from which ever angle you desire with the same game play area of its more successful predecessor. And when it starts to get stale or you want a feature from a mod in SC4 just go look on the workshop - there are a country load of quality mods - and if not you can build your own. So I am going to agree with all the reviews I saw and shout from the tallest rooftop I can build that Cities: Skylines is well worth its title. Its aiming high and not far off being there.  Definately a recommended game from a long term fan of Sim City 4 - SC4 is dead - long live Sim City 4 - Cities: Skylines now rules the roost on this PC...

First off, I like this game. I waited for several years for a new and decent city builder to get released and when EA didn't step up with Simcity, I was glad that someone else did. Cities: Skylines has its strong points, and some definite weakpoints, but it's a fun game to play. There is a lot of content in the base game, it is a solid experience even without the DLC, and the community has introduced some wonderful mods that take things even further. You can make it more challenging for yourself, or less challenging so you can just build to your hears content and see what comes of it.   With that said, some of the building tools can be quite irritating when they don't want to do what they should, and some of the managment and zoning elements aren't the greatest. On top of that, I sometimes joke that this is a traffic simulator more than a city building simulator once you reach a certain point in a towns' development.   I am also not a fan of paid DLC that doesn't bring considerable content to the base game, and from what I have seen, their DLC is hit and miss on whether the hefty 15 dollar introductory price they charge is worth it (especially for disasters, which is standard city builder stuff). But even if you don't want to buy the DLC or you want to wait for the price to come down, the base game will definitely keep you entertained for some time.

It's more of a road network building simulator than a city simulator. All of the zones you zone and all of the buildings you build are there to drive traffic in & out of your city. 90% of your planning and building and organizing goes towards the road network, to the point of micromanaging and obsessing. 90% of the problems you will face when laying out your city will be road related.   Building the city just involves dragging zones with a paint tool and plonking down service buildings like hospitals and schools. All the cities end up looking and feeling very, very similar. The cities are very easy to build and grow. The only real challenge you ever face is designing a road network that flows and is not chaotic. This is fine. This can be fun. This can be interesting, and challenging. But this does not qualify as a city simulator.

Most negative review said it: it is not a challenging city building game.  My problem with Cities: Skyline that it is not a game really, it is just a tool to build huge beautiful city, somehow an editor with minimum challenges that can be easily solved by any one, and sometimes by itself.  Cities: Skyline unfortunately does not reflects a working city simulation, for example the cims do not need to reach work place, and the will stay happy and the industry will still be working, cims also teleport to another places with no need of road connection like university or school, those things make the game not challenging and put me off, cause I know if I start to plan my city in proper way as in real life I will not make it better, working simulation is a backbone for any city building game, and cities:skyline just did not do it right. I held my negative review for long time just to see if the developers will do something about it, but no, they released after dark DLC and the problem persist, and I do not think they inted to change anything regarding the simulation.  Other small things in the game that put me off: unnecessary building of water pipes and electric lines, just wasting time in my opinion, small farms, no air pollution and no disasters.  I know many people enjoying this game and that is good for them, but if you are looking for realistic city building with challenges please stay away. However, if you like to just build a nice looking huge city and look at it and take screenshots, this game for you.  To conclude, cities: skyline is very nice toy and really enjoyable one, but it is not a game with challenges or even reflect a city building simulation by any mean. If you are looking for challenging and working simulation city buiding games get something from Tropico series or Banished.

I wanted this game to be great so badly! I was a huge fan of the Sim City games back in the day, and I wanted this to fill the hole left in my heart by the recent Sim City titles that let me down. While the game is originally very fun and challenging it quickly becomes dull and repetative. After the first few hours playing it becomes excedingly easy to expand your city as your learn the pattern needed for growth.   As a result of this the replayability of the game is relatively low, and the only thing left that is 'challenging' are the achievements and unlockable buildings which are not very exciting and don't, in my opinion, offer a lot to the gameplay.
