The killer for me: The traffic simulation is some of the worst I've seen. Roads are difficult at best to get to connect correctly and many of the tools to control them are cumbersome and illogical at times. The sims love to form city wide single file lines that cause massive jams. This would be meh if the actual cars on the road didn;t actually represent a real jam that would disrupt actual other elements. Dump trucks, hearses, fire trucks, etc, will all get stuck in massive lines of traffic. sometimes only a single car wide on an otherwise empty 6 car roadway. There's nothing wrong with this type of mechanic, but you have to have a good AI behind how the cars move through the city. Many just go in endless loops all day long, never going anywhere. You always have to assume every citizen is in their car driving around 24/7. Coupled with the inability to transition between some road types and for a lack of true intersection control without complex modding, trying to figure out the roadways is a nightmare. Unless you really like to figure out bad AI systems and try to find ways to game them into working properly, this is not your game. Making simple highway to roadway interchanges is an exercise in frustration and working long hours for a goal that will either look awesome and like a logical city layout OR work perfectly with the crippled traffic AI.... but never both. The only real way to avoid the logjam is to create lightless cities that are nothing but one way streets and roundabouts. Even one traffic light or stop sign out of place (that you won;t have control over anyways) will eventually lead to a paralyzed city, even with low populations. This breaks so much of the other mechanics of the game that without cheats and mods galore, it's tough to enjoy it.   On to the DLC:  Honestly wait till it comes with the completed game or something. Many of the features only work on some maps and even though you would think there would be simple seasons, there is not. There is perpetual summer or a slog through what is a rough estimation of Alaska on a few maps. Many of the other features given are meh and become annoying at best most of the time. Night is so dark you have to turn it to day to actually work anyways, rain makes it impossible to see even a few feet so you turn it off anyways even if you don't have other DLC.  Limitations:  Cities are tiny and very limited. You can build a much larger city within the confines of a large regional grid square in SC4 than you can with what they let you unlock for areas int he vanilla game. There isn;t much point, though as the building cap severely limits your cities to what will nearly always have to become a tight cluster of sky scrapers to support a large population. Granted it takes a while to get to the building cap, it's only a fraction of the space you can actually unlock and once you hit it... that's it. nothing will grow and the game is immediadely stalemated. You can tweak and cajole but you will never get it any bigger. Also, even if you wanted to create multiple cities on separate maps and trade between them like you could in the flop Cities XL (which was an awesome concept, just poorly executed), or in a regional sharing of demand like in SC4, no. Everything is one big city per map (districts helps slightly), and there is no way of linking multiple city maps together.  Any good at all?  Like so many games in this genre, there is an awful lot of good stuff. The buildings are awesome and even though the AI sucks, the representation of traffic using cars that actually have to obey some rudimentary traffic laws and congestion is a great concept. The map squares, pollution, and other sub-systems are some of the best and most logical I have seen. All over the place there are awesome things I've never seen in a city simulator, and improvements to many things I have seen. The poor execution of the traffic, though, and the overall lack of sprawling multi-city gameplay, or even large city gameplay kill everything I love about the game very quickly.  Should you buy it?:  If you like great detail, great visuals, and are willing to spend ALOT of time working around complex tools and engine limitations, sure. Check youtube, it IS possible to make some great cities in this game. The learning curve and number of work arounds to do so is obnoxious at best and rage quit worthy at worst.   If you want a city simulator with robust tools, smart AI, Large scale gameplay, and intelligent design options... they haven't made one yet. Maybe Cities Skylines 2, or Sim City 6, maybe Cities XXXXXXXL will pull it off, I dunno. For now I'm a firm believer that the right company could make the holy grail of city sims, it's just not this company.   If you can get it and all it's DLC for less than $15USD... give it a whirl. I got frustrated with the road placements and traffic debauchary within 16 hours... maybe you'll last longer. It's not a bad game, it's just not polished and smartly designed.

I can't speak for anyone else, but this is one of the worst games I've ever bought.  When Maxis moved from Sim City 4 to 'SimCity' they did a number of things I strongly disliked. One of the biggest was downsizing the map. Another was, for lack of a better term, 'cartoonizing' the graphics and the way things are done; like how roads are laid. I again preface this by saying I can't speak for anyone else, but for me, this game has everything I hated about SimCity, and nothing I liked from Sim City 4.   Add to that these restrictions on doing stuff based on population size. I spent my entire playtime wondering what the heck was going on. 'Why can't I access my taxes. Why do I have income if I have no taxes. What is my city doing?'. I was also shocked by the lack of options for many things, and the strange language used to describe things in the menu. Perhaps for ESL folks (English as a Second Language) 'Edge Scrolling Sensitivity' means the speed, but for me, I, at first, assumed it was the size around the edge where scrolling would begin. I was also never able to figure out how to slow down the speed at which I scrolled around the map using the keys.   Add to that the fact that this game runs poorly on lower-end computers. I meet all the requirements, but this game is as smooth as sandpaper. I've had some serious issues before with Colossal Order games and what I felt were their misleading 'requirements', and at the time the only reason I did not demand a full refund was my respect for Paradox, the publisher.   Well that has it's limits. The moment I'm done writing this (and posting a copy of it to the Paradox forum) I will be looking into how to get a refund for a steam product. I've never done it before and likely will never do it again; and even if it turns out I can't get a refund (I bought the game on sale) I won't be broken up about it; but to have a game that I honestly feel is WORSE than 'SimCity' - which, I note is a game so bad that when I moved, I literally left the install CD in the otherwise empty Garbage Can. I was going to leave it on the table for the next resident, but then I realized that would be cruel - to have a game WORSE than that, is just an embarrassment to myself and my ability to judge a good game prior to purchase.

How did this game get good ratings??? After just 30 minutes, I can easily say this is a horrible city builder. It is way too difficult to do things like build a road and line it up properly for your zones. The controls are absolutely atrocious. Painful just trying to exit one function to do something from another menu. UI is just that terrible. How do you draw a straight flippin road in this game.... its not intuitive at all. Why do you hide the zones when you're placing an object???? Am I supposed to guess where my residential zone ended so I can place my school there... really???? This game has the potential to be fun, but the controls and gameplay just ruin it for me. Literally took me 30 minutes to realize I couldn't even find the bulldozer function... horrible design. Something important in a game with lousy contols is the bulldozer . It should be a prominent button, probably in this game with a flashing icon, since you will use it constantly. I was hoping this would replace the equally awful SimCity online, but its just as bad, just for different reasons.

Maxis did, with squares in 2003, what Colossal Order seem to find impossible in 2015, with a fully flexible 3D engine.   Why do I need a highway to start a city? High Capacity roads are towards the last end of a city's growth pattern. The building feels sterile, with huge gaps between buildings, and no personality for the city as a whole.  Also, no Day/Night cycle? Again Maxis did that in 2003 with dynamic lighting!!! We should have dynamic weather and random events and seasons.  If this ever gets fixed then I'll gladly buy this again, ... for less than £10 in a future sale.

Unfortunately it falls incredibly short of (my) expecations and, certainly, the over-hyped nonsense touted by much of the gaming press before its launch.  It's very difficult to 'fail' at a city, unless you've never played a SimCity game before and have no idea what you're doing. I've maxed out my budgets, plonked down all available monuments and just expanded and expanded and expanded... And money just keeps rolling in.  And that's roughly the point at which you realise that's all you're doing. There are no significant disasters that pop up to give you cause to alter your strategy or deal with adverse situations. Even using 'green power' has no real disadvantages so why would you build anything else?  It has an annoying 'Twitter-esque' notification which tries to convey what your population seems to be thinking, but it repeats nonsense so often that you eventually beg for a way to disable it and its annoying sound.  Your cities feel largely lifeless (since that Twitter notice seems to be as 'in touch' as you get with your people), you'll be plopping down safety services every other street because, apparently, they don't know how to drive further than a few blocks and generally... it just stops being 'fun' after its predictability becomes apparent (give it an hour or two, max).  If only Maxis and Colossal Order joined forces to make SimCity--it could've been wonderful. Each would complement the other. A pity though, that both simply fall horribly short of a genuinely *fun* experience.  If you're looking for a fun 'city sim' of sorts mixed with Settlers of old, give Banished a look. It's a bit tricky to get the hang of but the experience is infinitely more rewarding than this mindless game of plonk roads, zone 'em, plonk some more, don't forget to keep the utilities in order, plonk and zone some more, yawn...

No town hall upgrades or achievement popups? Besides the animation, zoom detail, placing trees, and road building, this game brought nothing outstanding, instead took steps backwards (I have to pipe my entire sewage and run power lines? Ok why? Talk about micro management) I bought this hoping that it would crush the things that I hated about Simcity, but instead I found that it created dozens of it's own new problems. I have to find out what is left to unlock but so far. If I had to choose between spending $30 here or $15 on eBay for Simcity I'd choose Simcity in a heartbeat.

I love the idea behind this game and have put more than a few hours into it, but I'm ultimately uninstalling it due to bugs and poor performance.   There are a lot of bugs (like noise being emitted from underground tunnels, buildings spontaneously toggling between water / no water even though there's plenty of surplus and all pipes are connected) and the game slows down too much to be enjoyable past around 50,000 residents even on a quad-core. This type of game shouldn't require a monster gaming rig to be enjoyable.   I wouldn't recommend until the gameplay bugs are worked out and the game is optimized to use the CPU much more efficiently.

Linux Buyers Beware This game is entirely broken on Linux with the standard radeon graphics driver of Fedora 21. Their support says to install AMD's proprietary fglrx drivers to fix it. Recent versions of the Open Source radeon graphics drivers work just fine with many 3D games from Steam like Dota or Civ 5, but Cities: Skylines itself is just broken. Installing fglrx drivers is not an option because it is incompatible with the desktop environment GNOME 3 as shipped in Fedora 21 and it makes the system otherwise too unstable.   The game works in Windows and is quite fun. I just wish they would fix it on Linux.
Say goodbye to free time.

Cities: Skylines is a last-gen city simulator with updated graphics, pastel vehicles, the same five building spawns and imbalanced gameplay. In my latest city, I had 5 dumps each having 15 garbage trucks (75), 2 cemetaries with a total of 1600 dead folk, 4 police stations etc. Do small towns of 7,000 produce that much garbage? Do Skyliners die at the age of 5 on a regular basis? Are all the cops in town at the donutsville donut shop not patrolling the streets of my town hence why I need a station in each of the four corners of my town?  With so many services you'd think I'd be running a deficit but I'm not. I don't know if that is even possible. No matter what I've done, I've always made money. Coverage is an issue. Even with all the services I've plopped the entirety of the town (according to the green highlighted streets) is not fully covered.   What makes this a last-gen game is laying water pipes, electric lines, the osmosis of water and electic of nearby buildings to others, multiple service buildings of the same sector having to be plopped all over the city (how many elementary schools does a town of 7,000 need?) to name a few. The lack of the little touches such as day/night intervals is also an issue (most of the world doesn't live in Norway and enjoys regular day/night cycles).  The one thing it seems to have going for it is the purchasable adjacent lands. This is what people who enjoy such simulations were crying about and so CO delivered. It does not improve upon the quality, balance or personality of the game yet this *one thing* has satisfied the hoi poloi.  I would recommend this game if it were polished, balanced, up-to-date with the decade we live in, and being finished. It falls short of 1st class city simulator but it has a large map.

This game may work with linux, but I haven't managed to get it working on three, up-to-date linux computers. The first one had an integrated graphics card (which Paradox says it does not support.) On the other two with standard (very good) cards, the game wouldn't start. Their support was diligent, but there are limits to how much back and forth I am willing to go through to play this game on linux.  Update: Well, I did finally get it working -- as in it runs. But it runs so jerkily and with such lag that it is unplayable even with 16-32 G of RAM. I literally spent five minutes trying to rotate a roundabout before giving up. Even moving around the map is so laggy that I end up with a largely random view.  Don't buy this game if you expect to run it on linux.
